Fallout New Vegas is an amazing game.
With that said the game does have a problem.
It's unstable if you don't find ways to fix the game it might crash on you often or worse not work at all.

Now onto the positives.
This game offers you :
Meaningful choices
Enjoyable aesthethic
Variety of weapons AND ammo types.
Charming companions
Morally grey factions to help at your choosing.
GOOD DLC's
A unique story and background lore for its locations
Customizable character
A portable ingame radio that you can turn off.
Mods.
Easter eggs to hunt.

The negatives :
The gameplay is a bit janky and the game can be very unstable but that can easily be fixed by reading the discussion threads and mods.

I like that the game doesn't ask me to give pointless reviews. If you have NEVER heard of Fallout New Vegas, then you likely have no reason to play this game. If you HAVE heard of it, then you likely already own it or are in the process of downloading it and out of sheer boredom ended up reading my review.

Either way, the game is awesome but being asked to give a review simply by accidentally clicking a thumbs up button because I was distracted by my kid wanting a high five is a downer. Not the high five, that was absolutely epic. Kids are awesome. User reviews are not. 

If you have kids, I hope they give you lots of random high fives and always want your attention. Enjoy it while it lasts. Then, when they go to sleep, go raise hell in the Mojave in FO:NV. It's absolutely the best Fallout game ever.

fallout new vegas has a lot to offer someone who appreciates a cross between a old cowboy movie and a apocalypses. especially with the DLC practically being standard now you will have numerous opportunities to be a paragon, an outlaw, a mercenary and a rouge element. with 4 different "main" endings and over a dozen factions to side with, subjugate, organize or obliterate, you will never have a lack of options. while the game does have a number of technical issues due to it's age, the community at large argues that it's the best fallout game to date and the amount of mods including fixes, re-textures, new quests, companions and even DLC sized additions. FNV is an excellent choice for anyone looking to have a/multiple 60+ hour experience....or beating the game in 2, both being almost equally valid.

Barely runs, tried three different hacks to make it actually load in the first place. I know its an old game but don't sell something that doesn't run very well on newer machines. A user shouldn't have to download mods or ddls just to make it work. 

The game it self is good in parts and has some good story lines on side quests, but the creative engine at this time had issues with numbers of NPCs, textures and colours. But every time I go to load the game it crashes again and I have to check the file integrity yet again. If I could actually play it, then maybe I could recommend it. But users shouldn't have to go through this much pain just to run something they bought.

Even in the bargain bin Steam should not sell this game in its current form.

i love this game hoping for a new vegas remake :(

3rd update : If you follow the community guide, download the 4gb patcher, and all the anti-crash mods, this game can be fixed so that it's in playable condition. I haven't had a single crash in 6 hours of gameplay, since I patched and modded my game. It took me a while to get into this, the game starts slow and was riddled with bugs and crashes. Once I made it past that point I'm having an absolute blast, the world doesn't feel so small anymore and getting a dozen levels under my belt really improves the experience. A remaster of this game would be unreal, with updated textures, draw distance etc etc.

So, I'm leaving my initial review up for now, even though I solved the crashing problem with the community guide. It took installing multiple mods, signing up for websites, updating my windows libraries. A huge fckn pain in the a$$. This game needs a developer patch instead of relying on the community to fix the garbage. So far the story is good and the game play is what I would expect. At this point I wouldn't recommend it, go play something else. Fallout 4 is my favorite game of all time, which is why I'm giving this stupid game more effort than it deserves.

One of the best video games ever. If you have the patience to endure the constant glitches, ugly crashes and learn the mechanics in depth, Fallout: New Vegas is worth it. With 4 endings, countless builds and possibilities, the replayibility factor is something else to behold and experience. All of the DLCs are great. Honest Hearts is a welcome change of scenery and pace, whereas Old World Blues is hilarious and challenging. Dead Money is harsh, but still enjoyable. Finally, Lonesome Road build up and atmosphere are epic, with its difficulty making you spend those consumabes and truly fearing death, even at max level.

Top 10 Reasons Why I Love Fallout New Vegas

Style/Setting
Shot and dumped in a shallow grave before being saved by a robot cowboy, this is truly the wild west of the future. From the intro to the credits, style and charm oozes like a dapperly dressed ghoul on his last poker chip.
 
Music
Besides your handy big iron, the radio is your best friend. Awaken your inner cowboy as you stroll into town with what tunes ye’ fancy, you’ll be playing the OST for years to come.

Map Design
But when it comes to retrospection, what I respect the most about NV is in its game design. Handholding is a huge crutch of modern gaming, but NV leaves it to you all from the start. Find your own leads, or hell, just go fuck off somewhere else. There is a general intended path, but it funnels you toward the main attractions of the world perfectly without you ever realizing you’re being guided. 

Interactive World
And everywhere you go, you’ll leave traces of your growing legend. Help stop the town bandits stashed at the abandoned casino? Few days later, and you'll be hearing about your deeds on the radio. Depending on how you resolve quests, you’ll even hear different things from people around the game, reacting to your decisions. It enforces roleplaying, as your decisions actually mean something. 

Replayability
And oh, the decisions you can make. For most RPGs, I can only handle one playthrough. Even Skyrim was maybe 3 characters. New Vegas? Honestly don’t know. I played through all factions at least once, then maybe another 6 characters of various progressions since back then. Only game I’ve ever played with truly good “evil playthrough” options

Character Builds
Damn, you telling me you beat the game 4 times and still keep coming back? Hell yeah man, there’s over a dozen weapon types, from plasma to pistol to punch to puncture to projectile explosives… Or of course, you can beat the game as a Pacifist if you boost your noncombat skills, just ask Jake. Smooth talk your way to victory in actually satisfying battles of wit. Remember when games had good writing?

DLC
Need more game still? How about going to Zion National Park? Or a Survival Horror Casino? What’s that? You want there to be an overarching narrative behind the DLCs that leads to a dramatic final showdown? You got it boss, here, have a hundred different weapon mods too

Modding 
Someone say mods? You want MORE game?!.. Okay! The community is still pumping new content out all the time. Sure, new enemies, new weapons, new coat of paint to make it all pretty. But also many questlines, entire fan-made DLCs, some entirely new games (New California/The Frontier) It’s not all professional, but what comes in spades is passion, and I’m often very pleasantly surprised. 

Memorable Cast
Mr House.  Caesar. Yes Man. Benny. FUCKIN Easy Pete. Too many characters have beat the test of time, memes all the years later. But besides the actual characters, the writing and dialogue are just always razor sharp in tone and/or humor 

Nostalgia
I played it at the apex of my rpg marathon after getting an xbox, so it definitely formed many of my tastes. Retro dystopias like Bioshock will continue to be a favorite of mine. That’s it. Just recognizing rose-colored bias. I’ll always be hooked on you, New Vegas. (Add +100 hr played on Xbox)

Fallout: New Vegas, in many ways, does not feel like a major innovation since Fallout 3. Although there are some welcome quality-of-life improvements, the core experience remains the same, which is fine, as it is very entertaining. 

The guns feel nice to use, with the new iron sights mechanic an essential upgrade. I adore the overall sci-fi Western aesthetic and music, too. However, I cannot help but feel like the map is largely empty and lacking the necessary polish to make exploring it a pleasure.

There are a few more such instances in the game which make it clear what kind of pressure the developers of New Vegas were working under, especially the time constraints. Hence, many side quests are simple, yet very irritating fetch quests. This is rendered even more frustrating by the fact that the locations in the game all feel too spacious, and not compact enough. Navigating them takes ages.

Overall, I quite enjoyed the DLC, as well. To conclude, New Vegas could've been better, had the developers been given more time to truly flesh their ideas out. Either way, the final game thus feels just good enough to call it "great", yet blatantly unfinished and lacking polish.

A great game ruined by a bad PC port.

I played this on console a long time ago and loved it. I decided to try it out on PC only to see that it's pretty much unplayable on the platform. I heard the PC version wasn't great, but I didn't know it was THIS bad. Even after trying some mods that were supposed to help with stability and crashes, I was still getting crashes every 5-10 minutes. From what I've seen, this has been a known issue since launch and for some reason they never fixed the game. About 80 minutes into the save, I just gave up because I was sick of having to reload the game and redo certain sections constantly. I looked up more potential methods to help with stability using mods, file editing and config changes, and ultimately decided not to even bother with it anymore as I shouldn't have to do a ton of workarounds just to make the game functional. That's a bunch of time to look up and mess around with stuff when I could be spending that time playing a game that actually works.

I have a very high end system, yet the game remains unplayable because of how poorly it works on here. If you want to play this game, just play it on console. It won't look or run that well, but at least it will work. It's insane and unacceptable that this game exists on PC in its current state.

I have played this game a few times. There really isn't much more to be said about the game itself so I will use my review to just make an argument. So long as the company of Bethesda exists in the way it does and operates as is, it will never create a game that is this good or this beloved. Nobody talks about fallout 3, 4 or 76 in a positive light. Every time it is brought up in discussion there are a myriad of problems apparent to everyone. Nobody is under the illusion that this is acceptable or worth of any cultural value. To say Bethesda is a shadow of its former self isn't even descriptive because that presumes that Bethesda had a point in their history where they considered the quality of a game when making it. This game was an accident, a flash in the pan, it will never be created again and you should play it because of that fact. There is no game like this and a game like this will never come again. I want to be disproven. I want to have a good game come out of Bethesda. If they make a good game I will be truly surprised. Play Fallout New Vegas because as far as I am concerned this is Fallout 3 and the Bethesda games are just a cheap imitation made to impress the shareholders of Bethesda and nobody else.

[h1] Echoes of Adventure: Rediscovering Fallout New Vegas After 14 Years [/h1]

In the vast realm of gaming, there are titles that transcend time, leaving an indelible mark on those who dare to venture into their worlds. Among these, one stands out as a beacon of immersive storytelling, unparalleled freedom, and enduring allure: Fallout: New Vegas. As I embark on a journey to revisit this beloved masterpiece, I am compelled to share the profound impact it has had on my gaming journey and why, even after 14 years, it remains a pinnacle of the RPG genre.

[h2] Unveiling the Mojave Wasteland [/h2]

Stepping into the Mojave Desert is akin to stepping into a parallel universe, teeming with life amidst the desolation. With each stride, you traverse highways, delve into caves, and encounter settlements, each brimming with stories waiting to be unearthed. The attention to detail is nothing short of breathtaking, weaving a tapestry of realism that draws you deeper into its enigmatic embrace. From the first moments of uncertainty to the final revelations, every step in the Mojave feels like a revelation, an exploration of the human condition amidst the ruins of civilization. What sets Fallout: New Vegas apart is its unwavering commitment to player agency: 

[i] You are not merely a bystander in this world; you are the architect of your destiny. [/i]

Whether you choose the path of a benevolent savior or a ruthless opportunist, the Mojave bends to your will, offering countless avenues to carve out your legacy. The freedom to define your character's identity, motivations, and moral compass is a testament to the game's unparalleled depth and replayability.

In the crucible of conflict, your arsenal is your most steadfast companion. Fallout: New Vegas boasts a veritable treasure trove of weaponry, each as diverse as the roles you inhabit. From conventional firearms to outlandish contraptions imbued with fire and fury, there is a tool for every task and a strategy for every encounter. The seamless integration of weapon variety enhances gameplay, ensuring that each engagement is as exhilarating as it is strategic.

In the Mojave, every action carries weight, every choice a ripple in the fabric of fate. The beauty of Fallout: New Vegas lies in its commitment to consequence, where decisions echo across the wasteland, shaping the world and its denizens in unforeseen ways. From the desolate ruins of Camp Searchlight to the bustling streets of New Vegas, each locale is a testament to the power of choice and the enduring legacy of one's deeds.

As the sands of time continue to shift, Fallout: New Vegas stands as a testament to the enduring power of storytelling and the boundless creativity of its creators. Despite the passage of 14 years, its magic remains undiminished, beckoning newcomers and veterans alike to embark on a journey unlike any other. While the visuals may show signs of age, the heart and soul of the game endure, casting a spell that transcends generations.

[h2] Embrace the Journey  [/h2]

To those who have yet to experience the wonders of Fallout: New Vegas, I implore you to embark on this odyssey with an open heart and a thirst for adventure. Embrace the uncertainty, relish the freedom, and savor every moment, for within the Mojave lies a treasure trove of memories waiting to be unearthed. And to those who have traversed its rugged terrain before, I invite you to revisit this timeless classic, to rediscover the magic that captivated us all those years ago.

[i] In the annals of gaming history, Fallout: New Vegas stands as a beacon of excellence, a testament to the enduring power of immersive storytelling and player agency. So, don your armor, arm yourself to the teeth, and venture forth into the Mojave, where adventure awaits and legends are born.  [/i]

The best game in the Fallout franchise, and one of the greatest RPGs ever created. It used Fallout 3 as a base, continued lore set up by the first 2 games, and gives the player a ton (seriously) of choice to shape the world how they want to. There are 4 main endings you can choose from, and each side quest has at least 2 endings that are either reflected in the world or during the ending slides that tell you the consequences of your actions.

There is also a very active community of mod creators constantly releasing new and interesting content for the game, allowing you to play this for a long time. I've been playing it on and off for a decade.



The game has performance issues due to the game's engine and the developer's lack experience with the Gamebyro Engine and the GECK. You can fix the issues with mods.


Viva New Vegas is the best modding guide available. It goes over everything step-by-step. If you want the essentials, follow it until you reach the "VNV Extended" section.

https://vivanewvegas.moddinglinked.com/intro.html

I have done pretty much very thing that can be done in New Vegas. Having experienced everything, it is hard to recommend the game without many qualifications.

It's an incredible rpg that was a victim of circumstance. It is the second Obsidian rpg that was subject rushed development and a story that was too big for its own good, the first being Kotor 2. The game has an incredible story but everything between talking to different characters is alright at best. I understand why people might drop the game because of that, or because it's too unstable without mods, or with too many mods. 

It is also harder to look back on New Vegas because of the allegations against Chris Avellone, one of the lead writers for the game. The stories he wrote are some of the best in the game so  sucks that he is, allegedly, a horrible human being, as it feels really weird to praise his work now.

So to play this game without constant crashing, there are a few things you need to do:

1. Run the game in windows 7 compatibility mode.
2. Turn off Data Execution Prevention (DEP) for the FalloutNV.exe file. This can be done by going to System->About->Advanced->Performance->DEP.
3.Install the 4GB ram patch for the game. The game is 32bit, therefore only uses 2GB ram.
4.Install LOOT. This will help with mod load orders.
4.Install the following mods, preferably using vortex for ease of use:
         -Yukichigai Unofficial Patch 
         -New Vegas Anti Crash 
         -Johnny guitar NVSE 
         -Stewie Tweaks and Engine Fixes 
         -New Vegas Script extender 
         -JIP LN NVSE 
5.Launch the game directly from Vortex. This is in the top left hand corner, indicated by an arrow.
(OPTIONAL). look up guides online for how to do anything here. the mods are found on NEXUS, and make sure everything is compatible before hand. 

Hope anyone that reads finds this helpful. It took me a while to make everything work lmao.

Probably one of the best western RPG's in the decades. Buggy as heck cause they only had 18 months to work on it, but since 2011/12 I've played it without hitches or constant crashing; except for very, very rare occasions.
The fanbase for this game is a bit- how shall I say it... Political and Reddit-like. Look I love New Vegas, but if it weren't for Fallout 3 the franchise would've been dead with Brotherhood of Steel.
Would say give all factions a try, but personally I've now been unable to tolerate NCR's crap like I did as a kid cause as a 24 year old (at the time of writing this), the shit we're dealing with in reality pretty much is front-and-centre with the NCR's storyline/lore...
I would suggest buying this game in the event Bethesda sucked Microsoft's dick enough to suppress/hide it to improve Bethesda's sales for their RPG titles, like to what happened with Rockstar and the og 3D GTA games. Extreme case yes, but gotta end the review with a funny; just buy the damn game and have a blast!

P.S the reason it's not 10/10; needs a remastered version on the latest engine, and providing full development time, problem is that most of the talented folks who made this game are probably not even part of Obsidian anymore...

I think the game has a great storyline, it however is held back a lot by it's cutscenes and gameplay, the voice acting is sometimes mediocre, and while sometimes you can get lost in a character like Chief Hanlon, a lot of the actors are quite mediocre. The game has many noticeable plot holes, such as you being shot for stealing a tin can by the NCR after you killed Caesar and solved all of their problems they accept outside help with. The game is better than all other action rpgs in that you don't have to kill anyone, but the game lacks replayability due to it's side quests. There are some amazing moments here and there, but the game overall feels a bit stale in my opinion after a while of playing it. If you want an action real time strategy RPG where you can be anyone and do anything, go for New Vegas, but don't expect it to be very polished or to not encounter a lot of bugs, dated environments, and lack of care put into each area due to it's lack of development time.

Aside from its rushed development (over-ambition mixed with 18 months) and many technical problems (some carried over from Fallout 3 and others that first appeared in FNV), there is a vast and seemingly endless game world to experience in New Vegas, and Obsidian's hard work shows here regardless of the game's shortcomings.

With a truckload of quests, branching paths, intriguing characters, fun (though downright dated) combat, fascinating set pieces, versatile perks, and clever environmental storytelling that will keep you preoccupied and returning for more, you'll need a Fixer for how addictive this damn game is. Plus the DLC is a must-play - Dead Money being the best - no matter what naysayers might have you believe.

Every mission, side quest or interaction has at least 3 ways of completing it. Not only this but the choices you are confronted with are complex and not binary as opposed to how Bethesda RPGs feel most of the time. Being made in 18 months, even though that was the plan all along and you can't completely blame Bethesda, it stands as a marvel of how alive, unique and well written a game world can be. It is a world that you adapt to as you play, feeling more experienced as you delve deeper into the characters, lore and game mechanics. The ability to use this knowledge but also still have new experiences and fun moments creates an environment where you not only find yourself looking forward to loading a new game, but are actively thinking of the next two playthoughs you're going to do once you finish your current one. Not to mention the tutorial and Ghost Town Gunfight are the perfect introduction for new players and old. Yes, the game is unstable, being made in a short development time with talk from lead developers saying they probably should have spent more time on the bugs and less on "shinny objects". However, modding the game is really not that hard once you get a basic understanding and from there, you'll play it the way it was intended and then some. The community is so active and there are so many new and well developed mods, it really adds a ton more content and enjoyment. I know there was an uproar about the 84/100 on metacritic, but aside from the bugs a lot of the same dna is still in the game so personally I wouldn't look at the number and listen the fans. It is a cult classic and a favourite for most long-term fallout players.

[h1]Verdict:
7.5/10
B+
[/h1]

[h2]TLDR:[/h2]
[b] Unfortunately, the character limit on Steam forced me to shorten this review.[/b] 
FNV stands on an unstable foundation, its flaws veiled by the smoke of its positive aspects. Despite the widespread acclaim, many players turn a blind eye to the glaring issues at its core. While I genuinely enjoy the game, it's crucial to address its serious flaws.

[h3]Summery:[/h3]
•Extremely buggy without mods; though with mods, bugs persist, to a lesser extent.
•Many CTDs, even with mods.
•Rushed development with many cut content, particularly The Legion.
•Absence of post-game content.
•Limited use of reputation and karma systems.
•Limited choices of stat, perk, and, skill checks in dialogue.
•Instances of NPCs unrealistically trusting the player.
•The game forces you to kill Benny, or have him disappear.
•Sparse non-lethal options and pacifist roleplaying.
•Some factions have no ending slides depending on who you side with.
•The Fiends are always hostile; no way to ally or join them.
•Majority of quest outcomes follow a linear path, diminishing any player impact.
•Limited character appearance and gameplay customisation.
•Limited companion customisation.
•Poor implementation of character traits.
•Clunky gunplay, melee, and overall combat mechanics.
•The Pipboy interrupts the pace of combat.
•Special stats are unbalanced.
•UI is awful.
•You can't have multiple quest markers.
•Slow movement speed with no sprinting option.
•Odd and inconsistent movement, leading to random sliding.
•DLC pop-up spam during the beginning.
•Lack of distance indicators for places of interest on the compass mini-map.
•Invisible walls.
•The hotkey for changing ammo is "2" with no way to change it.
•No FOV slider.
•Lack of mouse acceleration option in in-game settings.
•Certain graphics settings locked behind the launcher and inaccessible in-game.
•No random events or encounters.
•Repetitive and frequently reused large empty interiors and environments.
•Repeated use of the same voice actors for different named NPCs.
•Talking to NPCs pauses the world.
•Story and characters have plot holes.
•DLC doesn’t effect the main storyline.
•Lack of animations during dialogues, often resulting in the "Bethesda stare".
•Underutilised crafting and survival mechanics.
•Underwhelming water exploration.
•Hit Detection is awful; hitting invisible walls is common.
•Most unique weapons being mere reskins with better stats.
•Underutilisation of weapon modifications, which are irremovable once applied.
•Loading screens dividing sections of The Strip and Freeside.
•Bad QoL such as having to rebind your weapons.
•Vats will target companions.
•Minor side factions have little impact on main quest.
•The Wild Wasteland trait was underutilized.

[h3]In Depth:[/h3]
As you advance in the main quest, you'll obtain pardons from both the NCR and the Legion, resulting in a reset of your faction reputation with them. This is totally contrived, illogical, and strains one's suspension of disbelief. Prior to the pardon, players can freely engage in widespread slaughter of NCR and Legion members. Seriously? The notion of being absolved of such significant crimes is a glaring example of the game's tendency towards protagonist worship. It communicates the message that as the player, you are exempt from the rules, undermining the worldbuilding.

Following the pardon, you can interact with Caesar or Ambassador Crocker. Both inexplicably place trust in you, regardless of any prior faction massacres that you may of committed. This unwarranted trust is a severe undermining of their characters. Both characters assign you quests, blindly relying on you, despite having no good reason for trusting you. Caesar tasks you with using the platinum chip to destroy the Securitron vault beneath the Legion's fort, while House wants you to activate the vault for his control. Regardless of your choice, Caesar unquestioningly accepts your account, never bothering to verify the outcome beneath the fort. This oversight becomes even more stupid if you had previously slain numerous Legion members before the pardon. This inconsistency detracts from an otherwise well-crafted character.

Mr. House, written as a super genius, paradoxically possesses one of the most stupid security oversights. His chamber door is secured merely by an unlocked terminal, guarded by a few Securitrons, with a convenient elevator to his chamber. In 261 years, one would expect House to have sealed off this vulnerability or at least added a password to the terminal. The existence of such a blatant plot hole is disappointing and is inconsistent with the character's intelligence. 

A more plausible approach could involve an investigative process to locate House's chamber, possibly with faction assistance. Rather than a unlocked terminal, the story could demand you to uncover the hidden location and, with the aid of a faction or alternative means, devise a plan to breach in to it. This would offer a more logical and engaging method to confront Mr. House, rather than the improbable reliance on an unprotected terminal leading directly to his most secure domain. Additionally, it would be reasonable to expect higher security around such a critical area,

The game compels you to kill Benny; there's no way to save him. Even if you untie him, he's highly likely to be killed by Legion soldiers. If he miraculously survives, he can escape through a gate and vanishes from the game, essentially mirroring his demise. Additionally, the oversight of leaving Benny armed while being held as a prisoner near Caesar raises questions about the Legion's security logic, especially considering that upon arriving at the fort, the player's weapons are confiscated while Benny retains his.

If you become vilified by the Legion, you can still fast travel to the Fort, mysteriously bypassing the Colorado River. Factions possess a seemingly magical ability to detect if you've committed hostile acts against them. For instance, if you kill a member non-stealthy, you'll receive a reputation penalty, even in the absence of any witnesses. This also extends to the Karma system as well, which feels like a tacked on feature without significantly contributing to the overall experience. 

Certain quests in the game offer linear outcomes with a illusion of choice. For example, the Goodsprings mission where Joe Cobb requests the player to kill a merchant who escaped his gang. The player is presented with a binary decision: siding either with the gang or the townsfolk. The lack of additional and peaceful resolutions in this feels out of place for a "roleplaying" game. One might expect multiple options for resolving this complex conflict, but the player is confined to only two outcomes, despite the potential for additional options.

Character and companion customisation options are quite restricted. Background and backstory choices are absent, and the age slider has no discernible impact, rendering the character's age pointless. Appearance options are limited, resulting in minimal reactions from NPCs. The character traits, though a promising concept, fall short, allowing only two selections out of a total of 10 (15 with DLC). Unfortunately, these traits are imbalanced, with certain ones clearly superior. A more robust trait system akin to CK2, where age holds significance, would of been better. Character builds tend to lack diversity, often devolving into the same repetitive mono-builds, akin to the Skyrim stealth archer. Melee combat feels monotonous, involving constant left mouse button mashing.

Special stats significance are relatively diminished as maximum skills corresponding to these stats can still be achieved. Notably, a character can reach 100 Speech with only 1 Charisma, rendering Charisma irrelevant. Endurance stands out as the most best stat, overshadowing others. Agility doesn't impact movement speed, and Perception can be overshadowed by the presence of ED-E.

As someone who pre-ordered the special edition back on the 360 and still has that copy, and who got every achievement, I can say that this is a fun game. But unlike what seems to be the popular opinion New Vegas was my least favorite one between it's prequel and sequel. 3 > 4 > NV is my ranking (haven't tried 76). At this point it's been long enough since I actually played 3 and NV that I can't recall the minute differences in mechanics that may have led to that preference... but what I definitely remember is that the setting of NV just didn't match my own vibe. Too much desert and I'm not at all interested in the casino/Vegas theme. Once I was inside some other location I had fun, but the overworld exploration felt like a bit of a chore.

All that said... I don't think it was worth what I paid for the special edition pre-order, but for the price it goes for these days on Steam it's definitely worth picking up if you like these Bethesda style games (I know Obsidian made this one... might be part of why I don't like it as much as the ones made by Bethesda? They also made KOTOR II and I preferred the first KOTOR).

[h1]"Ain't That A Kick In The Head"[/h1]
Fallout: New Vegas takes place during the year 2281 within the region surrounding the former city of Las Vegas (now called "New Vegas"), around four years after the events of Fallout 3, and roughly around 204 years after the Great War of 2077. Players take control of a character known as the Courier. While transporting a package across the Mojave Desert to the city of New Vegas, what used to be Las Vegas, the Courier is ambushed, robbed of the package, shot, and buried in a cemetery. Ultimately the Courier is dug out and recovers from their wound. The Courier then begins a journey to find their would-be killer and recover the package, makes friends and enemies among various warring factions, and ultimately becomes caught up in a conflict that will determine who controls New Vegas and the Mojave Wasteland.
 
[table]
    [tr]
        [th]About[/th]
        [th]Description[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]💾Graphics[/td]
        [td]Now the graphics in this game have not aged well either. Now granted it is a 12 year old game so it has aged a good bit, also the game engine was never anything to be impressed about either but its not bad. The game does look fine, and it doesn’t hurt the eyes, and yes you can mod it to make it look better. The graphics are not as bad as people make it out to be. I never had any issues with them. Rest assured in time you will get used to them and I think it fits the style of the game and gives you a nostalgic feel to it.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎮Gameplay[/td]
        [td]The gunplay is clunky, and has not aged well at all, but you will get used to it after a while. The game does have a V.A.T.S (Vault-Tec Assisted Targeting System) which pauses time to pick a body part to shoot which helps a lot. Besides those issues, the gameplay is incredible. Fallout: New Vegas has so many RPG elements to it. You can play basically anyone you want, and that’s a huge plus for a shooter RPG. You have so many types of enemies that are really dangerous, and some that are a breeze to go through. All from mutated rats, to godzilla looking lizards called Deathclaws that can destroy you in one hit if you are not prepared. I can go on for hours about the gameplay, but let's move on to graphics.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]📜Story[/td]
        [td]Fallout: New Vegas has a rich story and honestly the best in the Fallout franchise. With so many factions and so many endings, the replayability of the story alone is just mind boggling. Even the game ending is just an amazing moment and I love going through, it’s so intense. With many memorable characters with fun side quests, every playthrough I do, I feel like I'm seeing something new for the first time. The DLC’s are a must buy and cheap to get, as they have amazing stories as well and can really help boost your character too in terms of perks and unique playstyles. If you love a good, rich and dynamic story, please pick this game up, because you won’t be disappointed.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🕛Playtime[/td]
        [td]The amount of playtime is nuts! With one character alone I put around 100+ Hours and still had missions to do and adventure. The world is huge in terms of content. The DLC’s are so well made as well. If I install this game again I can easily see myself adding another 200+ hours. The amount of choices you have and endings is incredible. Definitely one of the most replayable games out there. If you get mods, add that replayability by 10x![/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎧Sound[/td]
        [td]The gun sounds are dated I will say (which is my only complaint in the sound department). The voice acting is really good in this game and the music is so fitting! The creatures sound absolutely scary and the bandits have good dialogue as well.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❗Bugs❗[/td]
        [td]I will say one thing that is a huge negative are the bugs. My goodness does this game has a ton of them. Now there is an upside to this and that you can mod the game to improve it. This game has an active modding community. You can get the Anti Crash Mod, 4GB Patch, and Unofficial Patch mod so you won't have any crashes (or rarely any) and many bug fixes.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔅Performance[/td]
        [td]The game can have issues of course. You will need to get some mods that fix crashes (check the bug section). Also the frame rate can drop here and there (well on my specs). The optimization has surely aged poorly sadly. definitely the weakest part in the game.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]✔️Pro’s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Incredible story
[*]Multiple endings
[*]Gambling in Vegas
[*]Tons of content
[*]Many endings
[*]High replayability 
[*]Awesome locations
[*]Fantastic enemy variety
[*]Amazing characters
[*]Great RPG elements
[*]Exploration is rewarding
[*]Huge modding community
[*]Tons of freedom interms of choices
[*]Music and sound design is amazing!
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❌Con’s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Clunky gunplay
[*]Graphics are dated
[*]Bugs/stability issues (mostly fixable with mods)
[*]Can’t continue the game once the main quest is beaten (fixable with a mod)
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🏆Rating[/td]
        [td]9.5/10
This game is worth full price without a doubt! If you get it on sale it’s a total steal.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔗Conclusion[/td]
        [td]This is one of the best games ever, no doubt. There is a reason why a lot of people say this is one of the best “if not the best” Fallout game ever made. You can get totally immersed in this game. You play whoever you want. You can beat this game without killing anyone as well. The freedom this game has is so rare to see. Yes, the game has some issues and has dated visually. Luckily the issues this game has is fixable. If you are looking for an amazing RPG game, you have to get this game. It’s one of the best games to have been released. Just make sure to get some mods to fix the stability.[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

[h1] Fallout: New Vegas, the Underdog Who Conquered Its Own Place[/h1]
[b][I]★★★★★
The GOAT[/I][/b]
[hr][/hr]

[I]Despite production problems such as budget cuts and short deadlines imposed by Bethesda on Obsidian, [b]Fallout: New Vegas[/b] found its own place amongst its brothers, not as a stillborn such as [/i]Fallout: Tactics[i] or [/i]Brotherhood of Steel[i], but as a sole bastard, misunderstood by the overlords of the franchise, but loved by the players.

Eccentric, playful and carefully built (despite its limitations and problems), [b]Fallout: New Vegas[/b] is a game of substance, one of the most recognizable and endearing titles of its franchise, despite Bethesda’s grand marketing campaigns to push its newer titles under the spotlight and cast a shadow over this gem.[/I]
[hr][/hr]
[h2] GRAPHICS [/h2]
[i]★★☆☆☆
Unsatisfying[/I]
 Fallout: New Vegas’ graphics were already ugly when they first saw light in 2009. The outdated engine took its toll on gameplay systems and on the world design, but none suffered more than graphics.

One could blame the rushed development or tight budget, which might justify but not excuse the use of outdated technology for the game’s development. However, if you’re willing to believe in those rough and brutish graphics, letting go of the need of being aesthetically pleasant, there is [b]much more[/b] down the rabbit hole.
[hr][/hr]
[h2] GAMEPLAY [/h2]
[i]★★★☆☆
Satisfying[/i]

Fallout: New Vegas is a captivating fusion of FPS and RPG mechanics. Its FPS elements, while rooted in the legacy of Fallout 3's mechanics, showcase satisfying gunplay and a diverse arsenal of weaponry. FNV innovated with iron sights, the strategic use of different ammo types and other small tweaks. While some FPS features, such as sprinting or dedicated grenade buttons, remain absent, Fallout: New Vegas's unique pace ensures a captivating gaming experience.

Also, it shines as a true RPG. A thoughtful approach to leveling, in which meticulous planning shapes definitively your characters strengths and weaknesses, is essential for success. Dialogue options demand careful consideration, as your words can impact the game's narrative and the reactions of its dwellers. The game's NPCs, despite the limitations in their scripting and voice acting, are designed in a way that gives them flashes of true humanity. Karma and reputation systems further enhance the RPG experience, influencing encounters, loot, and the overall trajectory of your journey.

Quests in Fallout: New Vegas consistently present themselves as intriguing challenges, offering a sense of accomplishment upon completion. The game's conclusion ensures that your actions and decisions throughout the journey will bear significant consequences, leaving a lasting impact on the world you have shaped.

[hr][/hr]
[h2]ATMOSPHERE & SETTING[/h2]
[I]★★★★☆
Mesmerizing[/I]

The Mojave Wasteland, despite occasional emptiness, presents a bleak yet quirky environment. Production issues may explain its sparse nature, but it aligns with the idea of the desert and its oasis, contested by powerful factions. It's empty so the few things it has jump to our eyes while we search for very little, in a very scarce place.

What redeems the game is its player-centric map design. In contrast to Fallout 3's sprawling but confusing Capital Wasteland, FNV features (more or less) well-connected towns, outposts, and marketplaces where small societies thrive. The northern crown jewel offers a central point amidst the vast wilderness, providing both interesting surprises and moments of terror during extensive journeys through the desert's sands and languid biomes.

The integration of a seamless tutorial, a clear progression route, and the enchanting narration by Wayne Newton, accompanied by iconic music, make the Mojave an enticing home for players who like to wander.
[hr][/hr]
[h2]STORY[/h2]
[I]★★★★★
Outstanding[/I]

[I][no major spoilers included][/I]
[spoiler]
Fallout: New Vegas takes place in the Mojave desert in 2287, in an alternate universe. In this world, microtechnology wasn’t developed further such as in ours. Without transistors, scientists employed their efforts in mastering atomic technologies, such as fusion reactors. A great crisis in fossil fuels and later atomic fuels pressured the new “Cold War” between the United States of America and China into total nuclear annihilation in 2077.

Nations slowly rebuilt, many years after the war, and in 2287, two new nations of this disfigured world are engaged in skirmishes after an armed conflict over an oasis, standing in the middle of the forgotten Mojave: New Vegas. While Los Angles, Washington DC, New York and other major cities fell quickly under bombardment, Las Vegas stood as the last bastion of the Old World. Its casinos opened up again, neon lights and extravaganza never seen before the Great War.

You are a courier for the Mojave Express delivery service, tasked with taking goods across the Mojave. One night, one of your deliveries takes a turn for the worse.

Left for dead, you have to regain your strength and walk again the Mojave after revenge, for you know, better than anyone else, the game was rigged from the start.
[/spoiler]
The game has rich lore, expanded thanks to the franchise’s original developers, who worked at Obsidian during the time of New Vegas. 
[hr][/hr]
[h2]DLCs[/h2]
[i]★★★☆☆
Satisfying[/i]

Here’s a list of the game’s DLCs, in the order I completed them, which [b]I recommend[/b]:
[olist]
[*] Honest Hearts→ Captivating story, beautiful although poorly designed map.
[*] Old World Blues → Fun, engaging and rewarding for curiosity. Not the best story.
[*] Dead Money → Challenging enough to make gamers work hard for it, but not so much as to be just a grind or impossible. It is the most difficult one of all four, and can be the most rewarding, as well. It brings in the game a component of horror which fits well. 
[*] Lonesome Road → Second most difficult one. Interesting story, intriguing and eerie atmosphere. Introduces interesting mechanics, as well as more locations for the player to explore before the endgame.
[/olist]

Fallout: New Vegas’ DLCs bring forth new weaponry, equipment, armor and interesting stories for the player. It must be noted that some DLCs, while short, can be tedious at times. Still, their characters are always fresh and interesting.
[hr][/hr]
[h2]PERSONAL TAKE[/h2]
Fallou: New Vegas is my favorite game of all time. I had it on the Xbox 360, I bought it for PC as well, and if they ever port it to newer platforms and it is a decent port, I’ll have it as well.

FNV is a mindset. I get lost in its world just like I do in GTA IV. It speaks to me in a personal level. It's an outstandng work of the game industry, a refined [I]magnum opus[/I] from 2009, even with all of its flaws, that stands the test of time with its everlasting and maturing qualities. No game that I have seen, so far, could quite replicate the same precision and tasteful artistic quality that Fallout: New Vegas had when portraying its story and world. FNV inspired other games and spawned Outer Worlds, another Obsidian title, out of its own success.

Fallout: New Vegas makes you feel a part of that world, it enables you to shape it however you want, but it will always punish you for the things that we forget: that war never changes.

I would like to see its legacy continue through creative choices in future games in the series, a hope that is naïve, to be fair, and through old and new players enjoying it and I'm pleased that I've been seeing it happening more and more.

New Vegas is an underdog that has shown very well it can be king by conquering its place in the hearts of fans.

And it probably can conquer its rightful place in your favourite games if you give it a try.

Fallout: New Vegas isn't just another game—it's an unparalleled gaming experience that has left an indelible mark on me. When it comes to freedom of choice, this game doesn't just talk the talk; it walks it, sprints it, and cartwheels through it. Want to be a machete-wielding maniac? Sure. A sharpshooting gunslinger? Absolutely. Or perhaps you prefer the dynamite-hurling approach? The choice is yours, and the possibilities are as vast as the Mojave Wasteland itself.

What sets Fallout: New Vegas apart from the crowd is its staggering array of weapons. From makeshift contraptions like dog tag knuckles to elegant firearms like engraved revolvers, the game's arsenal is a testament to creativity and variety. And let's not forget the explosive options, ranging from humble dynamite to apocalyptic rocket launchers—there's something for every wasteland wanderer.

But what truly elevates Fallout: New Vegas is its commitment to player agency. In a world where every decision matters, you can chart your own path without ever lifting a finger in violence. Align yourself with legionnaires, soldiers, or cunning gangsters—the choice is yours, and the consequences are yours to bear.

With four distinct endings and playthroughs that stretch into the double digits, Fallout: New Vegas is a testament to replayability. Each journey through the Mojave feels like a fresh adventure, with new discoveries and challenges waiting around every irradiated corner. As I embark on my umpteenth playthrough, I'm reminded once again why this game holds a special place in the annals of gaming history.

This game is absolutely fantastic. The narrative from start to finish is compelling, gritty, well written, and entertaining. You have the freedom from the start to begin leaving your mark on the New Vegas landscape, tangibly shaping the world around you. You can feel the atmosphere and environment change based on the decisions you make within it. 
For a game that I first played 10 years after it's release, I stopped thinking about it's age after character creation. The mechanics are somewhere between FO3 and FO4, which, in my opinion, affords it a replay-ability that far exceeds that of FO3. It shows the darker side of the Fallout universe, with characters and decisions as equally as dark. 
And if nothing else, there are fewer things cooler than wandering the Mojave delivering wasteland justice in VATS with Big Iron maxed on the Pip Boy.

The intro begins playing the song "Blue Moon" inside the casino of the Lucky 38 with a crooked portrait of the casino, the camera slowly rotating upright and moving away to reveal more of its surroundings. It proceeds to exit the casino, picking up pace as it tours the Strip while "Blue Moon" slowly becomes fainter amidst the background of the carousal about the street.

While on the Strip, we see the main hotels and a mixture of drunk NCR military members and civilians walk in the streets. Three Securitrons startle a pedestrian as they roll towards the Ultra-Luxe. The camera zooms out further to the perimeter of the auroral city to an NCR Veteran Ranger firing a lethal shot from their anti-materiel rifle at an armed Fiend just beyond the confines of New Vegas.

The camera fades out in flames to a distant hillside. A scout uses his binoculars to observe the city of New Vegas and outer Vegas, while explosions faintly ring around the city. Beside him is a banner, bearing the mark of Caesar's Legion. Legionaries rush behind him as a Legion explorer waves them through. Once more, the camera resumes even further from the city distinguishable only by its glow amidst the dark, night air of the Mojave. The scene becomes Goodsprings Cemetery, presently active with a small group of Great Khans digging a shallow grave intended for the unconscious Courier, and a man in a checkered suit standing only feet away, lighting a cigarette. The opening narration begins.

Easily the best of the 3-D Fallout games. New Vegas allows players to get involved in a world and story that is thought-provoking and funny without being too much of either. Every playstyle is well thought out and unique, giving anyone their preferred method of attacking or avoiding conflict. This game has more developed mechanics than Fallout 3 with a new damage and durability system, as well as new speech-checks (instead of a percentage chance, you have to have a certain amount of a skill). The only complaint I can have with this game is the graphics, They are rough and extremely dated, even for its time. Otherwise, this is an incredible RPG shooter. 9/10.

I played and beat this game once on the Steam-Deck. Overall, I think the game plays well using the controls. Only issue was with the weapon hotkeys - the corner weapons are a bit awkward to swap to. Up-right and up-left sometimes makes you swap ammo (triggered by the up button on the d-pad) which is really frustrating in the middle of the fight, because you start reloading your gun with a new ammo type that won't be helpful, so you press the button again (or several times to cycle through different ammo types) to get the right one. The only time I had to manually invoke the keyboard was at the very beginning when loading the game/ creating the character, and never again. 

It only crashed a handful of times near the end of the game. Otherwise, runs stable on the steam deck and I have had no real issues. There were maybe a few areas with lag - but surprisingly, not at hoover dam. /Might be a location based thing with certain areas in the game.

Diving into the gameplay itself: 8/10. Engaging story and really funny at times. The world was fun to explore. Really loved how all your skills felt useful, and you're not punished for not focusing on charisma like other games of this type. 

The DLC's were also phenomenal overall. Sierra Madre is my personal favourite (and the most frustrating) - it just felt the most accurate to the message of what Las Vegas was.

I wasn't a huge fan of modding the weapons, and think other games have better UI systems to do that, but it wasn't a big deal. Do wish there were more options when it came to modifying your weapons though. 

The weakest part of the game was definitely the combat. Whether it was the game engine obsidian had to use, the short timeline they had, or the effort being placed into other more important areas (or more likely a combination of all 3,) it's the part that has aged the worst. Shooting doesn't feel great, and some weapons don't work on enemies up close when you are in VATS. It feels like when you're out of VAT's, you can shoot somebody 20 times in the chest and only have 2 of the bullets actually make combat. The game makes up for less then stellar shooting mechanics with fun weapons and enemies, which saves the combat. Otherwise, if you've played any modern game that had guns in it, most of them will feel better then this. 

Will play again to explore other options. This is a good game. If you've been on the fence on checking it out, take the dive.

Fallout: New Vegas - 8/10

Fallout: New Vegas stands as a classic video game title, often hailed as a masterpiece and one of the greatest games ever created. During my formative years, I delved into the post-apocalyptic world of New Vegas multiple times on the Xbox 360—a title that managed to be both enjoyable and flawed.

The campaign is gripping, offering the allure of diverse endings. The inclusion of a karma system adds depth, prompting players to navigate the moral complexities of the Fallout universe. Will you seize and hoard, or adhere to a virtuous path? The decision to align with the NCR or Caesar's Legion further enhances the player's agency.

Engaging gameplay, coupled with enjoyable gunplay, makes battling unique and varied enemies a highlight. However, the game is not without its flaws, with potential game-breaking glitches cropping up, particularly during quests.

In essence, Fallout: New Vegas is a stellar title with the potential for multiple playthroughs, provided one possesses the time and patience to navigate its immersive, yet occasionally glitch-ridden, world.

Pros:
- Fun gameplay
- Great campaign
- Fun side missions
- Fun enemies (except for cazadors)
- Interesting characters

Cons:
- Game breaking glitches can occur
- CAZADORS!!!!!
- Most NPC's are clones.

Fallout: New Vegas.
The best true RPG of our lifetimes.

I should start out by saying; I am supremely biased. FNV was the first western RPG I had ever experienced when I got it on the Xbox 360 in early 2011, and since then I've played nearly 1,500 hours of it across 12 playthroughs of ~120 hours each. It is my favorite game of all time, but not necessarily because of nostalgia. Fallout: New Vegas has, to my mind, never been surpassed in its pairing of roleplaying and narrative flexibility, by any game since its release - and I've played The Witcher 3, so you know this game must have something special. Therefore, that's what this review must prove.

When you start a new game, most of everything you need to know about the plot of New Vegas is laid out for you in one of Fallout's many iconic slideshows, but if you are entirely new to the franchise, I'd suggest clicking here. Otherwise, I'll just state that New Vegas is much more connected to the stories of Fallout's 1 & 2 than 3 or 4, due to it being set on the West Coast, and is in some ways a continuation of the story from Fallout 2. The rest, I'd rather not spoil. Although, in this specific Fallout... You are a courier, hired by the Mojave Express, to deliver a package to the New Vegas Strip. What seemed like a simple delivery job has taken a turn... for the worse.

Due to the fact that the only stipulation placed on the backstory of your character is that you were at one point in time a courier, the character you create can essentially be anyone you want them to be. If you have the ability to coherently write a character, FNV becomes your own narrative playground; one of my favorite elements of the game. The character creation tools presented at the start of the game are suitably expansive as well; between skills, tags, and traits. Further progression in New Vegas is also superb, as you raise your skills accordingly and select from many game-altering, or at least useful, perks. The character creation and progression in FNV is exemplary.

In FNV there is a plethora of dialogue, choices, consequences, and other roleplaying mechanics to be found. These systems all work together in perfect harmony, which puts real weight behind your actions. This could even mean small actions, such as how you talk to a companion changing their character arc. Speaking of talking, the dialogue system is especially of note, as this is where most decisions are made, and where you express the personality of your character. There are always a stunning amount of choices you can make, and you'll never feel like a viable option was left out - in any situation. Many of your decisions even leave lasting effects on the Mojave, which I'll explain in greater detail later on.

New Vegas is well known for its intricately constructed faction system and politics, as you can choose from one of four main factions to end the game with, as well as affect nearly two dozen other minor factions - either by aiding or hindering them. Each organization has their own backstory and lore, and all of them have quest lines worth delving into. These groups will remember how you treat them, which builds a lasting relationship between them and the player. It's these dynamic factions that really bring the world to life through their thematic depth, and give the Mojave a lived-in feel.

Now that you have a sense of this game's successes, I'd like to highlight why it's my favorite game. Because of how incredibly detailed and lore-dense the Fallout series is, the jaw-dropping amount of narrative flexibility in New Vegas is what seals the deal for me. The ability to shape the Mojave as I see fit, a world that is so well realized, is unbelievably tantalizing to me; and I don't think any RPG has handled this better. It makes me feel like such a tour de force, that it's my character making these monumental decisions, and changing the future of a whole region - forever.

FNV takes place in the Mojave Wasteland, clearly, and the desolate design of this setting establishes a highly authentic apocalyptic atmosphere. I find the vanilla graphics to be timeless because of this, but mods can certainly modernize them. The region is a joy to explore too, as there are countless locations with pieces of environmental storytelling, quests, and loot within them. There's also an optional hardcore mode, which makes these barren wastes just that much harder to survive.

As a side note, I'll quickly state that almost every side-quest in New Vegas is spectacular. They were crafted with the utmost attention to detail, as they all have several ways to progress through them; and sincerely thoughtful writing applied to them. Each storyline has a distinct and often original motif, which makes them all a pleasure to play and experience.

Another important part of the game are the companions and characters, who all share one thing in common; purpose. Every follower has their own quests, backstories, and motivating factors that make them relatable to the player, and from even the most minor of (named) characters to the most important, everyone has identifiable personality traits. No one feels like wasted potential. These honest personas are what grounds your adventures in FNV, by making you truly care about the Mojave and its inhabitants.

Changing tone, Fallout: New Vegas' combat is fun, but also clunky. Shooting, stabbing, bludgeoning, disintegrating, and exploding your adversaries is what you'll spend most of your time doing when not exploring the wastes or having a pleasant chat, and this level of variety is where the strength of the combat lies. Just because it's clunky, doesn't mean there isn't visceral joy to be had. The V.A.T.S. system has also returned, but I don't personally use it. In essence the combat is just good enough to impress, but modding, which I'll mention later, can improve in considerably.

The biggest downfall of New Vegas is, undeniably, its performance. This is almost entirely the engine's fault; Bethesda have never been known for their technical aptitude in games creation - and Obsidian had to make do. Minor bugs run rampant, as well as crashes if you don't make necessary tweaks to the .ini files, which you can look up to discover what I'm talking about. The game also stutters often, but mods can alleviate this issue for the most part. My advice would be to save often, and install a few mods, which is the next topic.

One of the greatest parts about Fallout: New Vegas, and the post-Fallout 3 series in general, is its customizability. Anything from simple fixes to new quests, and visual overhauls to gameplay tweaks can be added to the game, and to do this I'd recommend the FNV Nexus.[www.nexusmods.com] I'd suggest watching some tutorials on how to mod the game, and from there NVSE, NVSR, NVAC, and Project Nevada are all essential mods as far as I'm concerned, but it's up to you. Visual mods are also welcome, however they're subjective so I won't recommend any here. All considered; modding: a useful skill for any FNV player.

I hope I've made my case as to why this is my favorite game clear. It's not the best at everything it does, but what it does do correctly is simply exactly what I want from a game. The roleplaying, decision making, characters, world, lore, narrative - and so much more, just binds together into such a cohesive package of everything I ask for from an open world RPG, that I can't resist it's call. And, if I remember correctly (but of course I do, I could never forget), it sounds a little like this...

[h3] Why I recommend Fallout: New Vegas! [/h3]

For anyone who takes what they purchase into consideration seriously, I'm sure you have already heard about Fallout: New Vegas' cult classic status; so to be brief, I would like to add a small part that many reviews leave out of the discussion.

Despite hailing it as the best RPG I've played and recommending it to genre newcomers, Fallout: New Vegas is not a hardcore RPG, however, nor is its combat system that deep. It’s a unique balance that's hard to find in the modern RPG landscape. It's straightforward to start playing, the world is engaging, and the systems, even without a tutorial, are fair and easy to understand. I would highly recommend it to anyone who's starting in the RPG world, rather than a Ubisoft or other Bethesda title; as decisions genuinely feel as if they have a tangible impact on the story. It’s a great balance between dialogue-focused RPGs such as (the more modern) Disco Elysium, whilst remaining engaging enough for players more familiar with FPS combat systems to jingle, jangle, jingle.

This is an important distinction, as Fallout: New Vegas, unlike other RPGs, always has an enduring sense of progression both in terms of narrative, but also gameplay. Although the balancing late-game is not perfect, it still represents the best blend of complex RPG systems with clear feedback. Clear feedback is often lacking in older and more rigid RPG systems from the late 1990s and early 2000s, where it was always unclear to what extent the skills had on gameplay. Fallout: New Vegas ensures that you have a clear understanding of how your character is progressing... Now ain't that a kick in the head!

That said, even with my 640 hours, clearly this game is not completely stable, especially on modern hardware. If you seek to play New Vegas regularly, installing some stability mods will ensure your experience won't make you wish for a nuclear winter.

[b] Let me suggest a stability guide! [/b]
[url=https://vivanewvegas.moddinglinked.com/intro.html]Viva New Vegas[/url] - is a modular vanilla-plus modding guide for Fallout: New Vegas that I use, as it has a step-by-step guide to ensuring you have a similar experience. For its simplicity, I would highly recommend Viva New Vegas!

this is my first review ive ever written on steam. that's how you know its important. all i have to say is that playing this game was an actual nightmare. when the game was vanilla, it would crash. once i installed all the mods that were recommended and then some, it still crashed. it was practically unplayable at certain points. i have to save literally every couple of minutes before my game crashes unexpectedly. i never had any of these issues when i played fo3 and i had to install some other thing for fo3 yet it has never given me any issues. to make a long story short, the story was meh, the dlc stories were ok, the play itself was horrendous because of the lag and crashes, and i shouldve bought it when it was discounted. its crazy to know that sawyer had to make mods for a game that has issue due to its rushed nature. 

the atmosphere was also not really it for me. when i think of fallout, i think of a post-nuke world. one that looks sad and empty, near destroyed just like fo3. i know in fnv it has been 'a while' since the bombs fell, but it still did not give me enough of a wasteland vibe. the world doesn't just fix itself quickly after a whole nuke falls. it needs to look around the same. they had a big chance to do this and make vegas lights and casinos look scary or apocalyptic... yet they didn't. that's a definite loss. i actually believe the only main thing i liked from this game was the faction honor system rather than a general honor system, as well as the disguises. that's about it. 

in terms of comparison: fo3 has yet to give me any issues and is definitely my favorite so far. it has crashed probably 1-5 times since ive had it and have played for around triple the hours i have for new vegas. new vegas is near unplayable even with the crash mods, johnny guitar mod, etc. etc. was not worth the full price. i wish i could return it.

tldr: i recommend it if you're very patient and willing to troubleshoot... a LOT. if you are impatient when a game crashes (i.e. raging) or hate saving super often or hate having to install add-ons to make your game even remotely playable, do not install this game. itll be a waste of time. most of the hours you rack up will be from having to reopen the game after it shits itself.

Recommendation: Mods. Dozens of them.

While I'm grateful that Bethesda, on their giant, fat throne of mediocrity, has revived one of the most original and replayable franchises of the '90s, it's indisputable that their treatment of it is nothing short of appalling.

Bethesda doesn't understand what Fallout is.

Bethesda games aren't tales about humanity or darkly funny satires. They are empty, soulless worlds, built as a playground that favors non-linear exploration. Bethesda's Fallouts are not about people. They are simply visual copies of iconic elements that were part of the original games, but without any depth in its context. Thoughtless.

Writing, in the artistic sense, in the sense of "constructing and saying something with words", for a change, is something almost non-existent in games like Fallout 4.

Wasting this universe in this way, having access to all the budget and talent in the world, is almost a crime.

But look: They at least know how to craft visually immersive experiences. Systemic worlds rich in environment details and atmosphere, inviting and easy to get lost within them. This must be why these games still sell despite all their problems.

But what if there was a game that managed to combine both things? A game that favors free exploration and little fun diversions in an immersive form and fills the gaps that gives context to the world with very well written stories full of charm and humanity? Really good characters? What if the world had some kind of aesthetic and narrative cohesion? Some overarching narrative juiciness that permeated almost every area of ​​the game?

What if we finally had a real "Fallout 3"?

This is New Vegas. A majestic obisidian stone, which dwarfs any effort made by Bethesda since then.

Problematic, technologically dated and lacking some mods to run properly, but inexhaustible in its brilliance.

Years pass and this game never seems to get old.

I can play Fallout 3 & 4 for ten years and not remember anything other than the controls.

I can go ten years without playing New Vegas and i'll still remember the cowboy robot from the casino. I will remember MR. House, Yes Man, Benny, The Burned Man. I will remember the vault with overgrown plants and the giant rusty dinosaur. I'll remember the giant killer flies. I would remember so much that I couldn't fit into Steam's maximum word count.

I frankly can't even conjure up enough words to describe how easy it is to get lost within this game. The groove, the stories, the main conflict, the characters, the ballads on the radio, the allure and beauty of the wastelands.

This is an open world game whose the monotony of this type of design doesn't slow down the experience. They managed to make a game so big, so narratively heavy, not feel extremely slow-paced, like most RPGS today and of the time, let alone CRPGS like the Original Fallout. The pace is just right. Delicious right.

And even the combat, which is its worst part, has a functional and satisfying simplicity, due to the sense of impact from the sound design and the balance of the difficulty.
 
It's simply fantastic.

HBomberguy (On YouTube) made two videos about Fallout. One about Fallout 3 (And how it compares to the originals) and another about New Vegas. These are perhaps the two best videos about Fallout that exist on the internet.

These are long videos that are very easy and fun to watch, which provide an in-depth analysis of the qualities of these games and, ultimately, propel any viewer to have a deeper appreciation of the successes and mistakes between Obisidian and Bethesda.

If everything else seems redundant in this review, at least watch the videos. They are more than enough.

Disable the game's VSYNC and activate the card's, limiting the FPS to 64.

Fallout: New Vegas is a true classic in the RPG genre and a staunch reminder of how the franchise went down the gutter over the years. The amount of decisions and different paths you can take is truely astonishing and shows how much work the developers put into this title, even though they were given only a rather short amount of time to work on it. 

Let's directly begin with the best thing of the game. The amount of freedom of choices you are given. You want to be a genuinely good person who cares about others and help the poor and powerless? No problem, just do it. You want to be a complete psychopath who murders his way through the wasteland, steals and lies to everyone, while even commiting heinous acts like cannibalism? No problem, you can just do that. Depending on how you choose to behave, the perk system will offer an absurdly high amount of character traits, that all feel quite unique. Add a massive arsenal of weapons, different ammo types and armor to it and everyone will be able to find something that fits his playstyle. The world the game throws you into is full of detail, interesting places to explore, strange and funny characters and different factions you can work for, work against or even join their ranks. The available DLC's are a must have and add different setpieces, more perks, unique items and hard decision to your experience. 

Now let's shortly talk about the bad stuff, because the game definitely isn't perfect. The stability and bugs can be a true problem and turn your fun experience into a frustrating one. Certain mods are basically needed if you want to get rid of these problems, thankfully they are pretty easy to install, even when you don't know a lot about modding. I also recommend some visual mods, because the game already looked quite outdated when it was released in 2010 and don't forget to add some quality of life features on top of it, like a better UI. 

New Vegas is a phenomenal RPG which has some flaws here and there, however the attention of detail the developers put into it and the high amount of replayability, will make you forget these smaller problems. 

Have fun!

This is one of my most cherished and favorite games of all time. Its quirkiness, storytelling, gameplay, all of it draws in me in better than what Bethesda puts out. They treat it like a black sheep but it's really that one successful sibling while its Bethesda made step-siblings who do have financial success but are generally frowned upon for a myriad of reasons. Like divorce lawyers.

Though limited because of an 18-Month Development Period, Obsidian delivered a treasured gem that gets the most attention from the fanbase outside of the countdown and release date of newer titles; Fallout 4 and 76.

When I got into PC gaming this game was one of my early go-tos after enduring a broken borrowed copy on Xbox 360. Throughout high school, during the days I was often bedridden during recovery from surgeries to my spine and left leg because of scoliosis. I played New Vegas most often on a HP Compaq nc8430 laptop (I was in a low income household, no money for gaming laptops) and aside from that - TF2 and Minecraft.

New Vegas is such a part of my life that during one of my surgeries I dreamed I was there in the Mojave Wasteland myself. The sun beating down on me, my only shade a cowboy hat and sipping a Sunset Sarsaparilla to quench my thirst. I don't remember much of it, only that it felt real and that I was content there. Someday I will visit the real Goodsprings, Primm, and so on. Maybe I'll even live there one day.

This latest playthrough was my "No More Tours" run, the end of the road for this Courier Six. Got all the achievements, did everything right (Independent/House, Nuked NCR and Legion, convinced the Khans to break their ties with Caesar and go East, etc.). Then I went back to my favorite modded player home (NV Novac Apartment) and decided to call it an end there.

I might start it up again, give the Mojave another go eventually but for now... It's time to rest. Kick off those spurs that jingle, jangle, jingle and leave the Big Iron in its holster.

To the devs that worked on this, to New Vegas itself and to that one bark scorpion I've always blasted on the way up to the Goodspings Cemetery.

Thank you and happy trails.
