In 2010 some of the people behind Black Isle Studios, the creators of [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/trar/recommended/38410/]Fallout 2[/url], got to make a next-gen addition to the series. Not surprisingly, it has better writing, better world-building and better gameplay than Fallout 3, not to mention more content and a better sense of actually [i]being[/i] a Fallout game. If you're a fan of the series and haven't played this yet, I 100% recommend this to you and you should probably go play it ASAP.


Fallout: New Vegas is an FPS-RPG hybrid like FO3 was, which means both traditional Fallout stat progression and real-time skill play a part in gameplay. Some of the stats influence how good your character is at real-time combat as well as combat in the VATS targeting system, which uses Action Points to determine how many actions you can take at once.

Those stats determine how much damage you do and how accurate your weapons are. Non-combat stats affect a range of other activities; Lockpicking for example lets your character break more and more challenging locks.


Like FO3, you can block using melee weapons. Unlike FO3, you can perform special moves in VATS if your melee skill is high enough. Ironsights on firearms can be used to aim (the shooting is usually alright) and the companion menu has been redesigned as an ergonomic radial. The Big Guns skill was also merged into the Guns skill.

Of special mention is Hardcore mode. It gives ammunition weight like in the classic games, which means you can't carry around 5,000 bullets and rockets anymore. You also have hunger, hydration and sleep to manage, and health items heal over time instead of all at once. It's both a throwback to classic Fallout and a newer challenge, one that I personally enjoyed.

It also makes the Survival skill - the continuation of the classic Outdoosman skill - that much more useful, making comestibles more efficient and letting you craft more items at campfires. The crafting isn't very intrusive or even strictly required; it's a neat alternative to looting and bartering for everything you need and a source of unique items.


The DLC, if you bought any of it, consists of four expansion packs with new areas, and two packs of additional items. I mention this because [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/trar/recommended/72840]one of these packs[/url] consists of items sold by vendors and additional Challenges you can perform with them for XP (although there is [url=http://www.nexusmods.com/newvegas/mods/46138]a mod[/url] to have the weapons scattered around the wasteland) and the other pack is a combination of the four preorder bonus packs.

You receive them at the very start of the game, so I would suggest turning them off for your first playthrough to avoid cheatiness. It's 99 cents, and you can separately enable each pack; of course on subsequent playthroughs I'd recommend it for the classic pack alone so you can have maximum Fallout 2.

Since this is a Fallout game, and a game developed with Bethesda's Gamebryo engine, it can be sluggish and buggy at times. [url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=164659260]This guide[/url] can help you optimize your game and learn how to install mods if you so desire. Aside from the mods linked in that guide, other mods I would recommend for repeat playthroughs include [url=http://www.nexusmods.com/newvegas/mods/42033/?]a mod that stops installed DLC from spamming you at the beginning[/url], [url=http://www.nexusmods.com/newvegas/mods/39218/?]a mod that improves NPC characterization[/url] and [url=http://www.nexusmods.com/newvegas/mods/37002/?]a mod that adds weapons from the first two games[/url]. That would be a good start for an enhanced game: the mod community for this game is huge.


As for the plot and writing, I mean it when I say it's miles ahead of FO3. New Vegas is an actual [i]good example of writing[/i] in a major videogame. The game world may still be pretty well-preserved for 200+ years after a catastrophic nuclear war, but the desert/frontier environment mean it's not totally unbelievable.

NV's main factions are well done. You have the return of the New California Republic, which is facing off against the raiders-writ-large Caesar's Legion over control of the Hoover Dam. (The Legion and the inclusion of the Dam originated with the canceled Fallout 3 originally being made by Black Isle, which is [url=http://www.moddb.com/games/f3-van-buren]currently being remade as a mod[/url].) In the middle lies independent New Vegas, as well as other smaller groups both familiar and new. There is depth and nuance to rival the first two games to the point where I was reminded of the classic book [i]A Canticle for Leibowitz[/i], which deals with similar themes and was apparently inspiration for some of NV's worldbuilding.


The game world does seem a little compacted, but that's largely a necessary gameplay conceit. You are somewhat railroaded at the beginning of the game due to quest progression and monster placement, but once you reach New Vegas itself, the game really does open up.

This doesn't strictly stop you from going anywhere on the map from the beginning, but you'll need skill - or a lower difficulty setting I guess - to get past the powerful monsters lying in certain directions. The first two games had this sort of soft railroading as well, so it's not without precedent.

The new radio stations are both less annoying than Galaxy News Radio and less gratingly repetitive than Enclave Radio. There's a good amount of ambient and incidental music too, some of which is even taken from the first three games and can be a treat to hear.


Overall, if you're looking for a good action RPG, if you have the time to spare for it & a computer to run it on I would recommend this. Just don't forget to optimize it if you're having trouble running it.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

Let me count the ways this game has tortured me:
- While offering some of the greatest freedom of any FO game, all end game choices resolve the same way - a battle at Hoover Dam that remains largely unchanged
- The achievements are dog shit. There's not a soul alive who wants to play 30 games of Caravan or eat 7 bajillion pieces of food while drowning themselves just to hit an artificial goal-post
- Repeat after me. OPEN WORLD GAMES SHOULD NOT HAVE GRIND ACHIEVEMENTS. It defeats the entire purpose
- The game is unplayable without mods. Period. If anyone else tells you otherwise, they're lying to your face. 10+ mods to fix bugs and apply QOL, and I was still crashing to the desktop and experiencing surreal amounts of jank
- For all it touts in terms of worldbuilding and great characters, even so you will be bored of them by the 25 hour mark
- Did I mention UNREASONABLE AMOUNTS OF JANK? 30% of the time my NPCs were hopping up and down like spazzing bunnies
- Several CTDs even after applying a medically unreasonable amount of bug fixing mods

I could go on. Back in the day when I bought this game I remember enjoying it, but upon 100%ing it, it is clear to me why I stopped in the first place.

One of the greatest games that I have experienced. If you are not a fan of role-playing, immersion, story driven style of game play, then I would recommend something else. However, for you folks out there with a imaginative mind and a keen interest in story telling, this would be right up your alley. Incredible world building, atmospheric environment, extremely content rich in story and depth, well thought out characters for both good and evil, I would also like to mention that FNV has very complex story telling abilities. There is no such thing as predictability in New Vegas, actions and decisions always have a side affect or consequence, plenty of grey and morally complicated characters, the game's conclusion is never completely bliss (just like real life) depending on your character, choices, morale, your ending will be heavily affected by this. Even if you chose a very honourable play through you will only achieve 80% happiness or satisfaction, 20% will be things out of your control. A grounded game with a Sci-Fi twist. Poor graphics and an old running engine, but this can be resolve with mods. Excellent game! 9/10.

I am a 45 -year -old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father raising my son, who is now 14 years old. My son won this game from his uncle, so we installed him on his computer and he started playing. Until the end of the week he had 24 hours in this game. This was horrible for me, because it was hard to find ways to spend time with my son, because he is always with friends or just watching Youtube. So I decided to do a Steam account and get this game to see if I could play beside him. I bought the game, chose my survivor and level and started playing, but I was stuck in what you should do. I asked my son for help and he organized a game for me to participate. I loved it, because it was the best time I spent with my son since my wife died. Since then, this game has approached me and my son again and now we spend time together away from home as well. This game reminded me that there is fun in everything, and I brought many happy memories to me and my son.

[h1]Fallout: New Vegas - Where war never changes, but bugs sure do![/h1]

[h2]Gameplay Impressions:[/h2]
New Vegas kicks off with a bang as you find yourself shot in the head and left for dead. But fear not, because nothing says "Welcome to the Mojave" like a good old-fashioned assassination attempt! The open-world exploration is as vast as the nuclear wasteland itself, and every decision you make shapes the narrative. Whether you're siding with the New California Republic, Caesar's Legion, or forging your own path, expect consequences – both hilarious and heart-wrenching.

[h2]What I liked:[/h2]
• [b]Choice and Consequence:[/b] Fallout: New Vegas shines in its narrative depth. Your decisions matter, and the branching storylines offer a level of replayability that's rarer than a bottle of Nuka-Cola in the desert. Each quest feels like a mini-drama, with multiple ways to tackle problems and outcomes that will leave you questioning your moral compass.
• [b]Wild Wasteland Perk:[/b] If you're not playing with the Wild Wasteland perk, you're doing it wrong. From encountering a crashed UFO to stumbling upon a refrigerator with a certain someone inside, the bizarre humor and pop-culture references scattered throughout the game add an extra layer of entertainment. Trust me, you want to embrace the weirdness.
• [b]Companion Dynamics:[/b] Your ragtag group of companions is like a dysfunctional post-apocalyptic family. Each one comes with their own quirks, stories, and combat skills. From the sassy robot ED-E to the suave sniper Boone, these companions are more than just glorified backpacks – they're your partners in crime (and irradiated mutant-slaying).

[h2]What I didn't like:[/h2]
• [b]Technical Glitches:[/b] The Mojave might be vast, but so are the game's bugs. From floating objects to occasional crashes, be prepared for a few technical hiccups. It's like the game's way of saying, "Hey, even the apocalypse has its glitches."
• [b]Graphics Aging:[/b] While New Vegas was a visual marvel in its time, the graphics haven't aged like a fine wine. Expect character models that look more like mutated mannequins than realistic survivors. It's a minor gripe, but if you're used to cutting-edge visuals, this might be a radioactive eyesore.
• [b]Combat can be Clunky:[/b] While the VATS system adds a strategic element to combat, the real-time shooting can feel a bit clunky. If you're expecting the precision of a military-trained sharpshooter, you might be disappointed. It's more like you're stumbling through the wasteland with a slightly malfunctioning BB gun.

[h2]Conclusion:[/h2]
Fallout: New Vegas is a diamond in the rough of the post-apocalyptic gaming landscape. Its engaging narrative, quirky humor, and the sheer freedom to shape your destiny make it a must-play for any wasteland wanderer. Despite its technical quirks and aging graphics, the Mojave Wasteland is a place worth exploring – just watch out for the cazadores. They sting, both in-game and to your pride.

What is there to say about New Vegas that hasn't been said? You start as a Courier and that is all you know about yourself. It's probably the most blank slate-start in the whole Fallout series, letting you be whoever you want (and if you ignore all the lore from Lonesome Road pushed onto you). Want to be a 16 year old kiddo from the wasteland doing their first job? No problem. How about Easy Pete, an old, weathered miner with a love for dynamite? Also easy. I even played a James Bond-wanna be who only used 9mm pistols and focused on Speech, Sneak and Guns, which is pretty powerful actually. 

The faction story lines all have the same beats but to different tunes, while the leaders and people giving you quests have very different personalities. Smug Mr House, who will turn 4 this summer, superior Edward Sallow, or Caesar, the NCR, or always chipper Yes-Man. 

The factions, so much fun, depth and love. Followers of the Apocalpyse all the way for me! They are my favorite in all of Fallout. Legion has suffered from the short time to develop and I think they are among the weaker factions in New Vegas, I don't like their LARP gear too much, but they are still interesting and certainly very strong and dangerous. And oh so many more, Elvis-fan boys, people trying to rebuild the US of A, bikers without bikes who want to be Mongols, not to mention the Strip's gangs/tribes! 

Then the quests as a whole, so much fun. Skills mean something, you can get results from SPECIAL, skills and perks. Interrogating someone can be done in several ways, from beating them up, being smart or mocking them. 
On that note, you can actually beat the game by killing no one, there are no mandatory kills, no Alduin you have to game, no Kellog that needs some serious not-looking because the companion you dismissed just in that room killed Kellog, no. New Vegas lets you finish the game without a single kill, without a single weapon discharge. On the other hand you can also kill everyone but children and Yes-Man (who respawns, spoiler, because he's a program, not a unique robot). 

Within the confines of the game and story you can be whoever you want, no Shawn, no Daddy, no Vault or tribe, you are just a delivery person trying to do their job. That is the only real limit, your job. 

And that is all without any mods! But if you add those, oh boy, things do get so much wilder! More guns? No problem, from photorealistic ones to mash-ups of base game guns. Mroe outfits? Easy too. And all the quests possible, some as big and even bigger than most DLC, almost bigger than the base game! 

Is it perfect, tho? No, it absolutely is not. Without mods it's rather unstable and buggy and can crarsh often, so hit that quicksave very often. It's not the best looking game, not even for its time, the gun play is probably also not up to snuff any longer, the blank slate-character is not for everyone...

I'd still absolutely recommend the game to anyone who enjoys roleplay, action and exploration in a post-apocalyptic world that is on the way of improving itself. (Just clean up the clutter and fill in the potholes, Freeside! Seriously, you've had 200 years to rebuild shit!)

Loved the gameplay and story but there are a few bugs.

Um dos, senão o melhor RPG que já joguei em toda a minha vida. O mundo é cheio de vida e cada história de um personagem -- até NPCs que seriam considerados "não importantes" têm uma história e quests interessantes pra contar, essas que fazem o jogador se desviar muitas vezes da missão principal. O sistema de leveling funciona bem e a gameplay é bem feita com alguns ressalvos, como a impossibilidade de sprintar no jogo. O lado negativo do jogo são os bugs: FPS caindo constantemente se não for feito o uso de mods pra concertar isso; missões que não iniciavam a não ser por comandos no terminal; NPCs no chão, parados andando contra um objeto, entre outros. O uso de mods melhora [b]consideravelmente[/b] a experiência do jogo -- talvez torne-se até necessário. 9.4/10.

I've grown up along-side "Fallout: New Vegas"

When I was was 12, I played Fallout: New Vegas on the PS3. It was the greatest story ever told in a video game, it was chock full of choices that made me carefully consider and weight the options, and I got to make them while spinning a cool revolver and wearing a cowboy hat. By the time I had finished the game, Freeside ran at 4 FPS. Nothing would ever top Fallout: New Vegas in my mind and my heart.

12 years later it remains my favourite game of all time, almost uncontested... with some caveats.

Firstly, it's a Bethesda RPG and 13 years old. I don't expect it to run like a dream but it'd be nice if it was just a little bit more stable. Throughout the main story, I'd estimate it crashed at least once for every two hours of gameplay. That's not including the repeatable hard-crash I found in my save related to one of the achievements. It's not something I would complain about really, and you can tell the game to save when you do nearly anything that might might increase your odds of crashing (like loading a new area for instance). (keep in mind, this is the un-modded base game)

I expected the performance issues, in truth, I've never had great computers, and I've been looking for a reliable way to play Fallout NV for almost the last 12 years. What I didn't expect was to be left slightly let down by the voice acting and some of the character interactions. The vast majority of the voice acting in incredibly flat. There are certainly a good number of stand outs among the voice talent but Matthew Perry, for example, really phones it in. Yuri Lowenthal is all over this game, and really presents a ride range of performances. I think where it usually falls short is in the delivery. I mean I can't blame them. There's a metric ton of recorded dialogue, and the vast majority of players probably read the text box and skip over the voice acting, so who cares if the read is a little flat. Just something that stood out for me as an adult coming back to the game. I feel like here's where I would cite some examples of good VO in the game, but all that really comes to mind is "Yes Man" and the Yuri's performance as the guy who won the Nipton lottery. 

The character interaction gripe is more about how certain interaction weave together. There were several times when I would approach a character and a text box would give me choices that implied I had "heard a rumour" about this character, or gleaned some level of information I just don't ever remember hearing. Many groups of NPCs have one "signature" voice line they will simply repeat over and over again when you walk in close proximity to them. For example, the Fiends would often ask me if I "like the sight of my own blood", many times over the course of a single combat, and multiple times per enemy. There's also the infamous NCR quote, "Patrolling the Mojave almost makes you wish for a Nuclear Winter".

You may notice I still recommend the game. Fallout: New Vegas is the greatest game of all time, despite the nitpicks listed above. The natural story progression woven around different factions with conflicting interests makes for a compelling and different experience nearly every time I pick the game up. Perhaps the most disappointing thing about my most recent hardcore play through was that I very carefully progressed through the story to not lock out any ending until I was almost finished. This means most of my decisions were motivated by the achievements in game and not by the choices and options my character would have chosen. I highly discourage playing like this unless you are a broken person like myself. In which case I understand: You had no choice.

In my opinion, One of the games greatest strengths is how sprawling the map is. Very rarely will New Vegas cram you into sewer tunnels and force you surface in various cut-off metropolitan piles of rubble (I.E. Fallout 3. And 4 to some extent). there are a few notable exceptions to this but the Mojave wasteland feels so much less claustrophobic than Boston or Washington. It's the sprawling setting combined with the aforementioned sprawling story that gives this overall feeling of a world that's truly alive. A world where people all say the same canned one-liners as they wander aimlessly around, but I digress.

Overall I returned to the Mojave wasteland to find the best things about Fallout: New Vegas still hold up, my grievances with the game became slightly more nuanced, and unsurprisingly, there were more than a handful of undiscovered NPCS, weapons, and locations that I wasn't able to find on PS3 before my FPS went negative and I had to restart.

Life changing game. Highly recommended. I'll pick it up in another 12 years if I'm still kicking.

[i] [b]Title: Arnie's New Vegas Adventure [/b]

[Scene: Arnold Schwarzenegger, dressed casually in a Fallout-themed t-shirt, sits in a dimly lit room surrounded by empty Nuka-Cola bottles and a massive TV screen displaying Fallout: New Vegas.]

Arnold: (With an enthusiastic grin) Ahh, ladies and gentlemen! It's time to dive into the wasteland once again! This time, it's not about Terminators or politicians, it's about surviving the Mojave Desert!

[Arnold grabs the controller and starts playing the game. The iconic "Fallout" theme music plays in the background.]

Arnold: (In his best Austrian accent) I'm ready to get my adventure started. In this game, I'm not the Governator; I'm the Mojaveator!

[Arnold's character, dressed as a Vault Dweller, emerges from Doc Mitchell's house into the wasteland.]

Arnold: (Excitedly) Look at this! I'm stepping out into the Mojave, and I've got my Pip-Boy ready to go! (Flexes his arm like a robot) Pip-Boy, activate! Hasta la vista, boredom!

[Arnold explores the wasteland, encountering various characters and creatures.]

Arnold: (Chuckling) Oh, look at this guy! (points to a friendly NCR soldier) He's more jacked than me! I bet he lifts Brahmin for fun!

[Arnold's character gets ambushed by a group of Cazadores.]

Arnold: (Fighting off the Cazadores) Get to the chopper! No, wait, I mean get away from the Cazadores! These bugs are tougher than the Predator!

[Arnold's character enters the New Vegas Strip for the first time.]

Arnold: (Amazed) Wow! The New Vegas Strip! It's like Las Vegas, but with more radiation and fewer showgirls. But that's okay; I'm here to party!

[Arnold's character tries his luck at a casino.]

Arnold: (Shouting) I'm all in, baby! This is like playing poker with the Terminator. He never bluffs!

[Arnold's character wins big at the casino.]

Arnold: (Celebrating) Yes! I'm on fire! I should open my own casino: "Arnold's Lucky Vault." Come for the gambling, stay for the bicep flexing!

[Arnold's character gets into a heated conversation with Mr. House.]

Arnold: (Mocking Mr. House) You think you can control New Vegas? You can't even control your own thermostat! I've got more muscle than your whole Securitron army!

[Arnold's character joins the Brotherhood of Steel.]

Arnold: (Wearing Power Armor) I feel like a walking tank! I'm the T-800 of the wasteland now, baby!

[Arnold's character confronts Benny.]

Arnold: (With a wicked grin) Benny, you made a big mistake crossing me! I'm going to terminate you with extreme prejudice!


[Arnold's character finally confronts the game's final boss, Legate Lanius.]

Arnold: (Facing Legate Lanius) You're a tough cookie, but you're no match for the Mojaveator! (Launches into an epic battle)

[After defeating Legate Lanius and completing the game, Arnold takes a deep breath.]

Arnold: (Satisfied) That was one hell of a ride! Fallout: New Vegas, you're fantastic! It's got everything: action, drama, and more radiation than you can shake a Geiger counter at!

[Arnold raises his Pip-Boy in the air triumphantly.]

Arnold: (Concluding) So, if you want a post-apocalyptic adventure that's as epic as my muscles, then get yourself a copy of Fallout: New Vegas. Remember, I'll be back... to play it again!

[Arnold takes a final sip of Nuka-Cola and flexes his biceps.]

Arnold: (With a wink) Hasta la vista, wasteland! [/i]

[b] In the Mojave sun, where the tumbleweeds play,

From the Strip to the Primm's roller coaster ride,
I navigate chaos with a swaggering stride.
Caps in my pocket, and a trusty plasma gun,
In the Mojave, my friend, the real fun's just begun! [/b]

Between the broad approach to most scenarios and character-building, the refined gunplay compared to Fallout 3, and overall worldbuilding and story-telling, this is one of bethesda's best collab efforts ever. Definitely worth the $30 to buy the ultimate edition which I recommend as you will get more out of it that way. The base game does have a lot already but you'll miss out on content that offers more options to tackle the base game excluding the stuff offered in the DLC areas and quests. My only gripes are the RNG can feel a bit wonky and the heavy focus on moral ambiguity. I get that is a lifelike system and that's fine but it bothers me as it can narrow and/or end your approach. Depending on how you go about things, a lot of quests or even items can be either missed or outright unavailable to you. That is a problem for a completionist like myself as I like to experience everything in one run. I am aware I could do a new run and do things differently, but it is annoying none the less and still you can't get everything.                                                                                                                                    
                                                                                                                                                     
Now that was alot to process; let me simplify it and offer more.                                                  
Pros                                                                                                                                             
-Improved gunplay                                                                                                                      
-Broader/improved playerbuilding                                                                                              
-More diverse and specified crafting options
-surperb writing and storytelling                                                                                                  

Cons
-RNG can feel a touch wonky
-Glitches, Crashes, and system compadabilty issues (Look for fan patches online to fix this)
-NEEDS MORE COWBELL!!!

Overall, Excellent game 9.5/10

[h1] Fallout: New Vegas - A Desert Epic of Choices and Consequences [/h1]

[h2] Review Date: [/h2]
January 15, 2024

[h2] Reviewer Name: [/h2]
Schqrk Reviews

[h2] Overall Rating: [/h2]
9.4/10 ⭐

[h2] Completion: [/h2]
100%

[hr][/hr]

[h2] Introduction [/h2]

Fallout: New Vegas stands as a pinnacle in the Fallout series, offering a sprawling narrative set against the unforgiving backdrop of the Mojave Wasteland. In this comprehensive review, we delve into the game's strengths, exploring the intricacies of choice, consequence, and the pursuit of power.

[h2] Graphics and Visuals [/h2]

[✔️] 🎮 Atmospheric Mojave: The visual design captures the essence of the Mojave Wasteland, with its vast deserts, dilapidated settlements, and neon-lit Vegas Strip. While not groundbreaking in its time, the game's aesthetic charm endures.

[✔️] 🖼️ Artistic Direction: The artistic direction shines in portraying the contrasting elements of decay and opulence. From the sun-bleached landscapes to the gritty urban sprawl, New Vegas achieves a unique visual identity within the Fallout universe.

[✔️] ⚙️ Modding Community: The game's graphics benefit from an active modding community, allowing players to enhance textures, lighting, and overall visual fidelity. Mod support ensures that New Vegas can compete visually with contemporary titles.

[h2] Gameplay [/h2]

[✔️] 🎮 Open-World Freedom: New Vegas grants players unparalleled freedom in navigating the Mojave. The expansive open-world invites exploration, and the nonlinear narrative encourages diverse playstyles, making every playthrough unique.

[✔️] ⚔️ Tactical Combat: The combat system, while sharing similarities with Fallout 3, introduces improvements. The introduction of iron-sights aiming and refined VATS mechanics enhances the tactical aspects of engagements.

[h2] Story and Narrative [/h2]

[✔️] 📜 Dynamic Narrative: The narrative unfolds dynamically, with player choices influencing faction alliances, quest outcomes, and the fate of the Mojave. The intricate web of choices and consequences creates a deeply engaging storytelling experience.

[✔️] 👥 Memorable Characters: Fallout: New Vegas introduces a cast of memorable characters, each with distinct personalities and motivations. From the enigmatic Mr. House to the charismatic Caesar, these characters contribute to the richness of the narrative.

[h2] Audio and Sound [/h2]

[✔️] 🎵 Evocative Soundtrack: The game's soundtrack captures the spirit of the Mojave, combining Western influences with post-apocalyptic vibes. The music enhances the atmosphere, whether wandering the desolate wastes or navigating the bustling New Vegas Strip.

[✔️] 🔊 Superb Voice Acting: Strong voice performances bring characters to life, adding depth to conversations and interactions. The voice acting quality enhances the emotional impact of pivotal moments throughout the game.

[h2] Settings and Customization [/h2]

[✔️] ⚙️ Robust Customization: New Vegas retains the S.P.E.C.I.A.L. system, offering diverse character customization. The inclusion of Traits and the expansive perk list provides players with meaningful choices that impact their journey.

[h2] Content and Replayability [/h2]

[✔️] 🔄 Abundant Quests: The Mojave is brimming with quests, each with multiple approaches and outcomes. The wealth of content, combined with the game's branching narrative, ensures high replayability as players explore different paths and consequences.

[h2] Pros and Goodness [/h2]

[✔️] 🌟 Dynamic Storytelling: Fallout: New Vegas excels in dynamic storytelling, allowing players to shape the fate of the Mojave through their decisions. The branching narrative creates a sense of agency, making each playthrough a unique narrative experience.

[✔️] 👥 Intricate Faction System: The faction system adds depth to the narrative, as player choices influence alliances and conflicts between major factions. The intricacies of faction relationships contribute to the complexity of the game world.

[h2] Cons and Drawbacks [/h2]

[❌] 💭 Aging Graphics: While the graphics hold up decently, the aging engine becomes apparent in comparison to more modern titles. Despite community mods, certain visual limitations persist.

[❌] 💔 Occasional Bugs: Like many open-world games, New Vegas is not without occasional bugs and glitches. While these don't significantly detract from the experience, they may interrupt immersion.

[h2] Additional Comments [/h2]

[✔️] 💬 Additional comments: Fallout: New Vegas is a testament to the power of player agency in shaping a game world. The dynamic narrative, diverse characters, and the intricate web of choices and consequences establish it as a standout title in the Fallout series.

[h2] Why Not 10/10? [/h2]

Fallout: New Vegas, while exceptional, falls short of perfection due to aging graphics and occasional bugs. These minor drawbacks, however, pale in comparison to the game's strengths, offering a narrative masterpiece set in the unforgiving Mojave.

[h2] Overall Summary [/h2]

Fallout: New Vegas stands tall as a narrative triumph, embracing player agency and choice in the vastness of the Mojave Wasteland. With its memorable characters, dynamic storytelling, and intricate faction system, New Vegas secures a commendable 9.4/10 rating.

[h2] Fallout: New Vegas, only 18 months in the oven, one of the best ovens [/h2]

    Fallout 3 had already been released and with it the saga had been launched once again, now in 3D and with all the support of Bethesda to continue standing, so the next installment of this universe is launched, being the case of Fallout: New Vegas, a delivery developed by Obsidian, which despite the short development time and wreaking havoc on its launch, went down in history as an icon of Western RPGs.

    Released on October 19, 2010, Fallout: New Vegas is an open-world RPG with touches of a first- and third-person shooter set in the science fiction universe of Fallout, in which we take the role of a messenger from New Vegas. whose mysterious package is taken from him and after almost dying, he sets out to find those who tried to end his life.

[b] Below, a list of positive and negative points experienced during my time playing and free of spoilers (do not consider this as an absolute truth, but as what it is, a simple opinion) [/b]

[h3] What did I like? [/h3]

🟩 [b] History [/b] It has an absolutely wonderful development, considering abandoning the black and white between good and evil, and bringing it closer to a gray scale.
 
🟩 [b] Gameplay. [/b] Maybe not perfect, but it has a balance between action and roleplay that is very pleasant to intersperse depending on the situations you want to expose yourself to.

🟩 [b] Real importance of decisions [/b] one of the few games where our decisions will really mean a pronounced change, so you have to think about everything twice in advance.

🟩 [b] Music. [/b] Totally personal, but I consider many of the songs that were used for this title as memorable, even outside of their original objective.

[h3] What did I NOT like? [/h3]

🟥 [b] Performance. [/b] just like Fallout 3, presents a large number of bugs, glitches and errors (which exponentially increase their frequency in expansions)

🟥 [b] Aesthetics. [/b] just like Fallout 3, really disappointing, working based on the Creation Engine, both the modeling, textures and animations are notoriously crude and lazy, even for its time.

[h3] What should I take into account when playing? [/h3]

❕ [b] Recommended use of mods [/b] If the gameplay becomes unstable, the use of third-party mods is recommended to obtain good performance during Gameplay.

[h3] Personal opinion. [/h3]

    The western RPG par excellence, an incredibly dense story, surrounded by a living world in constant action where everything we do will be important for its development, which in the face of its technical failures, is really crazy as it was worked on for only 18 months at the hands of obsidian.

This review used to include a lot more mental jumping jacks. Honestly, it was kind of cringe, so I'm rewriting it since I've just recently began another playthrough.

New Vegas is my favourite game of all time. It means a lot to me. This was the game that cemented my love for video games as a whole. This was the first game that really forced me to actually think about the choices I was making and how my character's actions were influencing the world. This was the game that introduced me to the concept of grey morality.

I have a lot of fond memories of this game. A lot of nostalgia. It really is just a great game, and a lot of people have explained why that is better than I ever could. If you want a good video to sleep to, hbomberguy on youtube has a video essay about this game. It's a good watch.

Its also important to note that NV isn't perfect on its own, and a big reason why I love this game as much as I do is because of how much fun it is to mod it.

I'd never play pure vanilla FNV and I highly recommend you don't. The Viva New Vegas modlist is the definitive way to play the game in 2023. It's a lightweight, performance and bug-fix focused modlist maintained and curated by notable members of the modding community.

Best 3D Fallout game without a doubt, it's a gem of gaming.

The best aspect of Fallout New Vegas is the level of writting quality and open world design, almost all of its side quests revolve around the main story which creates a very well build and believable world, can't say the same about Bethesda's fallout games.

Just like any fallout game, you're free to explore and go wherever you'd like, but generally speaking this time of freedom leads to an unorganized and poorly paced story.
In New Vegas, as soon as you drift away too far from the route to the main story, it blocks you with an "organic difficulty".
For instance, after leaving the begining area, you wouldn't be able to take any of the shortcuts to the main objective since they're overrun by extremely difficult enemies for beginner. 
It forces you to stay on the main route but you still have the freedom to try or come back more experienced.

It's gameplay and gunplay are obviously dated and stiff, yet it still manages to be enjoyable and satisfying , but I admit it's not perfect. If we could add Insurgency Sandstorm's Gunplay to New Vegas it would be incredible.

Unlike Fallout 4 it's an actual RPG ; you can play an evil playthrough ; when receiving a quest, you can complete it in different ways ; if you are poorly skilled in certain field to complete a quest, you are never blocked, you can find another path to complete the quest.

Which is why Fallout 4 is not an RPG, for most of its quests the only choices of completing it, is either following the linear path without any alternative way or just ignoring it. 
And the Fallout 4 highly forces you to complete it, in Fallout New Vegas never does it forces you to use a specific mechanic or to complete a quest unless it's the main story and you obviously have a lot more possible outcomes.

It genuiely impresses me how a game made in 2010 in only 18 months has way more depth whereas Fallout 4 probably had 5 or 7 years of development and yet it so mediocre in every aspects.

New Vegas' technical quality is obviously its worst aspect, it crashes a lot and by "a lot" I mean A LOT ! But given the fact it was given only 18 months to develop, I don't blame it on Obsidian... I blame it on Bethesda, like always.

I enjoy Fallout New Vegas about as much as Fallout 4. I know Fallout 4 isn't exactly the world's favorite Fallout, but the dialogue menus are actually good, the story I haven't gotten too heavily into but I can tell from the missions around it that the story is going to be decent, and I haven't encountered many bugs.

Summary:
+ Few bugs
+ Faction Armor is better
+ Perks/Skills are better than Fallout 4 Skill Tree
+ Dialogue System feels Immersive
+ Karma and Faction Perception is better than Affinity
+ Weapon Durability and Armor Durability feels Realistic
+ Full Roleplay, lets you pick teams/sides
+ Companion Commands are more in-depth
+ Companions feel more fleshed-out as characters (without FO4 Affinity Quests)
+ The quality/variety of ammo feels more immersive and realistic
+ The different forms of currency feels more immersive and realistic
+ Rads don't *just* limit your health, they also weaken you - more realistic
+ Weapons generally feel/sound better to use and have more noticeable trade-offs
+ Weapons feature a "middle ground" between being old-fashioned but still having clearly evolved since the atomic bomb, but not to the point of feeling Sci-Fi.
* No settlements
- Lack of Underarmor and Armor Pieces (like Arm/Leg armor pieces)
- Creating a character is disappointing for a 2010-ish game
- You can't customize areas designated for you like you can in Fallout 4's Home Plate
- Repairing guns in your inventory feels overpowered
- Accessing the appropriate workbenches can feel challenging coming from FO4

Review Disclaimer:
- I am a programmer!
  - I suck at making games so while my ideas may be kind-of okay, they can still be very far-fetched for game design. 
  - I've tried making games, and I'll stick to making text-based games like you'd see in DOS-era, thank you very much! 
  - I dabble in things like AI and game engines - despite my repeated failures in making my own of either, so I do genuinely know a little bit about the limits of Fallout's game engine as well as the limitations of AI models.


=== Descriptive Review ===
Bugs Found:
- I have encountered one random crash that mostly occurs when I load a save right after loading a save, but to be fair, this game is a little bit more dated than my PC, and it's reported as just being a hardware/software clash with the engine (which I rant about for EVER by the end of this review)
- I also encountered what *seems* to be a bug with the one nice lady in Primm wanting Radscorpion Glands in exchange for casseroles. I obtained the glands - both of the usual variety and of the "Bark Scorpion", and the game forces my character to say I have none. I checked the wiki and couldn't find the issue, so maybe it's something wrong on my part. My game IS unmodded.

Things I miss from Fallout 4:
- Settlements, or at least a way to customize a "home base" like Home Plate
- Mods being fully baked-in (I'm lazy when it comes to mod loaders)
- I am only 17 hours in, but I still have no power armor. I don't know if it's absent or if it's more mid-to-late-game, but either way, having power armor is a must
- Being able to repair weapons in my inventory feels a little overpowered to me. I can carry 12 shotguns, merge them around a bit, somehow wind up with better damage-per-second, and keep my mods?
- I miss things like the Weapons and Armor workbench from Fallout 4. I think being able to specifically craft mods is a better idea than just buying them, however I think the mods should probably be made without an actual "workshop" like in Fallout 4 - requiring all the gear to be in your inventory first.
- I prefer the Fallout 4 way of doing armor modification, having multiple tiers and having armor for your arms, legs, torso, head, etc. I also like the layering armor, having under-armor as well as over-armor, and being able to wear all sorts of other stuff.

Things I prefer in New Vegas over Fallout 4:
- Karma is far better than Companion Affinity! It feels more balanced and holds you more accountable
- The way different factions treat you is 100% better in New Vegas, letting you pick sides with the "bad guys" and really get into the fact it's role-playing.
- The Skills and Perks, along with how SPECIAL integrates with them, is far better. It provides more fine-grain control over what my character is good at, and lets me make changes to my characters' specialties more mid-game and requires far less research into skill trees.
- Dialogue in Fallout 4 is literally the worst, New Vegas (and I believe 3 as well) takes the cake.
- I almost want to say the bartering system is different in New Vegas. I 100% prefer the idea of having different faction currencies in New Vegas, but I almost wish factions would force you to use THEIR currency and you have to trade it around somewhere else, making it more "realistic" in how a post-apocalypse would work
- I prefer the Rads system in New Vegas, it doesn't limit my health, it just makes me easier to kill - which is kind-of how it should be. It makes me weaker in attacks as well as health, makes my overall character fail at stuff, and is pretty realistic.
- I significantly prefer the concept of weapon durability, different types of ammo, and mods in New Vegas over what Fallout 4 has. See above though, as I feel there are things missing from New Vegas as well.
- I like the weapon variety in New Vegas better
- I like the idea that companions refuse to wear armor of factions they do not approve of, which to me helps immersion. I haven't checked to see what happens if *I* wear the armor of factions others don't approve of, but I'd say if those factions don't approve of the armor and shoot at me, THAT is good immersion too!
- I like the idea of having companions in New Vegas that are less "Here I am, here's my story, I'll shoot stuff", and them actually being fully fleshed out characters that you almost have to use charisma to get to travel with you. They don't just offer and pester.
- Companions in general are better in New Vegas, I like the stories and characters so far with companions, and I like how they deal with commands and such. Further, I like how they don't have a direct affinity (seemingly), nor do they directly connect to karma, but they DO have likes and dislikes you should probably respect (as far as I can tell). It's not like they'll kill you for it, but they'll give you a piece of their mind

Additional Notes:
- Fallout 4 limits you to side with objectionably "good guys" without DLC, and even forces your hand with the end-game faction like the Institute. New Vegas, on the other hand, lets you literally join the Legion and Powder Gangers, two of the well-known bad guys without debate.
- I've noticed non-engine bugs being much more rare in New Vegas than Fallout 4
- I noticed the RPG aspects are FAR superior in New Vegas.
- I definitely prefer many parts of Fallout 4's immersion via armor and personalization aspects. 
  - I also feel Fallout 4's character creation is 100x better than New Vegas.
- Skills and Perks system in New Vegas is vastly superior to Fallout 4's Skills Tree, and the Karma and Faction Perspective systems (where you get Good/Bad Karma as well as factions liking/hating you) FAR FAR FAR surpasses the system used in Fallout 4, which uses companions to punish you, but has absolutely annoying effects with settlements where you can get killed over a bowl of Noodles.
- The immersion of the Karma is superior.
- The immersion of dialogue is superior.

[h1] I'm about to get crucified by the internet. [/h1]

but to hell with it, I'll play devil's advocate.

TL:DR: It alright, not as good as I think many people believe it is.

Before I start, I want to say that New Vegas isn't an inherently bad game, there are things about it I absolutely love, but its absolutely overhyped and sold so many nostalgia goggles that the fucker selling them could buy a yacht. Also, before anyone even asks, my favorite RPG is KoA: Reckoning, there is no Bethesda fanboy here, thank you.

New Vegas is a game with *mostly* good writing plagued with standout poor decisions, a dated engine, and what I feel is an empty and incomplete setting. Gameplay for its time was better than 3 but it still has one issue I will bring up later.

Without Further ado; Lets start our review with the Courier himself:

[h1] A blank slate except not really [/h1]

New Vegas, as a whole, has some solid writing behind it and has concepts that I find generally interesting in a post-apocalyptic space. The Strip and Mr. House are interesting, the NCR is interesting, the Legion is... interesting but also boring except we'll talk about that later. The Courier is by far the most interesting out of everyone in my opinion. He (or she) is an enigma, someone who is only referred to by profession alone and is the catalyst for change in the plot of New Vegas. The ambiguity of the character truly allows you to make them who you want...
...unless you install Lonesome Road, where a backstory is forcefully shoved into your character, limiting aspects of that "blank slate" previously set.

This was a "Jump the shark" moment that felt way more forced than it needed to be. It takes away the charming enigma of the courier, and just causes weird plot inconsistencies (If the Divide was so pivotal to the NCR, how in the fuck does *nobody* in the NCR even recognize or refer to the courier, even vaguely? Unless Doc is just the greatest surgeon on the planet that just does not make much sense) that were best left never created.

[h1] RPG elements perhaps a little *too* open-ended [/h1]

Fallout is a game that is defined by the Skill-Check. It forces you to make compromises on what your character is, in order to make specific situations fare either better or worse for you. We all know speech is busted in this game but that is not something I wish to necessarily focus too hard onto for this review.

What I take issue with, is that you can build your character paradoxically to itself.
S.P.E.C.I.A.L. and Skills (of which skills compromise almost all of the skill checks) are completely separate from each other, which at first glance is completely fine. It opens up more options to the player and makes build flexibility. Unfortunately I think that there should have been some limiter on how far you can advance skills based on your S.P.E.C.I.A.L. stats.

Case in point: 1 Charisma 100 speech, while hilarious, makes zero sense unless you also put heavy points into Luck. You can be the unluckiest person in the wasteland, where every conversation with you is equal to an active hostage negotiation, and yet you can BS your way through everyone and everything. If New Vegas did not put such an emphasis on the RPG aspects then maybe I could let this slide, but this is a heavy RPG game and it just feels off to do something like this.

I know you can make the argument of "people can learn and improve over time", but it would make more sense with having to level your S.P.E.C.I.A.L. to improve skills even then. Whenever you practice something, you focus on improving the fundamentals (in this case, S.P.E.C.I.A.L.) first, then you move onto the more advanced stuff (skills) after you've grown comfortable with your level of understanding of said fundamentals. I would argue that this would make a better RPG system where both skills and S.P.E.C.I.A.L. genuinely matter, forcing you to compromise much more taxingly on combat over speech and vice-versa.

[h1] Objectively evil, nonsensical Faction [/h1]

I know, I know: "They wanted to expand on the Legion but they ran out of time".

Unfortunately, we are not talking about what they *wanted* to do, we are talking about what they are *in-game*, and the Legion is a faction so comically evil in their actions in the Mojave that they might as well have a monocle and a Dick-Dastardly-esque moustache. They enslave people, they burn cities to the ground, their "Initiation" involves slaughtering other tribes nearby. For a game that so heavily alludes to the "Moral grey-area", and that not one faction is simply "the best" for the mojave, these guys are as black-hearted as Jack Horner. 

Plus, its an extremely hard sell to compare savage, *legitimately misogynistic*, and extremely violent tribesmen following a flawed interpretation of ancient history to "ya know, democracy can be convoluted sometimes".

Unless you're an anarchist, this isnt a complicated choice.

[h1] About as interesting as the real Nevada [/h1]

The world just feels empty and souless outside of Freeside, The Strip, and a few areas with genuinely good side-quest stories. I like exploration and I like it when any game regardless of genre encourages it. New Vegas feels as though it does not encourage exploration for the most part. It likes to heavily imply "go here this way" many times, especially early on, and often punishes you for the mere thought of not going where it tells you to by making you fight high-level enemies. The amount of times I walked into a cave thinking "Maybe there's something in here" only for it to be maybe like 6-7 enemies and nothing else makes my soul feel indescribable pain. The strip itself is also kind of a let down, its a handful of large buildings and some smaller stuff tucked in there just a tad. If you told me that Reno from Fallout 2 would be a more interesting place than *Las-fucking-Vegas* I would think you'd need to be admitted to a psych ward.

[h1] A lot of tell, but very little show [/h1]

This is an issue that is more or less constant with Obsidian when it comes to non-isometric RPGs, they often have a good idea of scope and can write well for the most part, but they cannot do environmental storytelling to save their ass. Everything in NV is explained to you in long, excruciating detail. It may as well be a novel with a game on the side. It's hard to necessarily "see" what the characters talk about outside of a few specific instances and the world has very little impact by your actions outside of the ending slideshow. Learning about the world boils down to playing 20 questions with any named NPC and its fucking boring. What dialogue that doesnt just loop you back to the beginning options are essentially: "positive response", "negative response",  "snarky jerk/funny haha response", "[Skill #] Skip quest step".  Ironically, these are the same basic responses that Fallout 4's dialogue got so much flak over, but here its fine?

[h1] Was buggy, still is buggy [/h1]

Something something mods something something bugthesda.

Jokes aside, I'm not considering mods when talking about the game that the Developers themselves made, I got angry with Fallout 3's instability so I have to stay consistent. Unfortunately, New Vegas is every bit as buggy as 3 from what I have seen and can remember. I have been told its a massive improvement over when it first released, but they haven't been able to iron everything out and it still does show even 13 years later.

[h1] Final Words and Other Things [/h1]

I don't want this to come off as though I hate New Vegas. Its a fine game, worthy of being called an RPG even. There are characters I do like and factions I think are really good, but I don't see this as the "Best RPG of all time", not by a long shot. Other, newer games like BG3 and even indie titles like Undertale and Disco Elysium do what this game tries to do in terms of dynamic storytelling much better.

Certainly a pioneer of the genre, but it does not hold up *that* well.

i have little doubt this is in the top 3 of best games to ever be made. some games try to sell the game on a "no playthroughs will be the same" but they fall flat, largely because the world doesnt react to anything exept major things. this game delivers.
when fallout new vegas was made the devs thought up an amazing idea: for every quest or action you take there will be one reaction from the world outside that quest. it seems like a mediocre idea at best, but since you will likely not remember every quest you do this will make the unknowing player think "how did they make this world so reactive!?"
the quest design is awesome, the perks, traits and stat point system is superb: there are few games better than this one. it of course has its flaws, such as the occasional crash and the (slightly) dreaded entity load-unload glitch. (to solve that one, just tab out and back in.)

This is my favorite game of all time. The game play is fun and engaging, if not a little outdated. However, the shining beacon of this holy creation is the story. The story is not only beautifully crafted, with branching paths and true player freedom, but it also doesn't take itself too seriously. One moment I'm contemplating the true merit of being human in an apocalypse... then the next, and Elvis wannabe gives me his cyborg dog to go get brain surgery. S tier writing right there. I genuinely feel that this game should be studied as the pinnacle of RPG writing and game making. It's a shame that Bethesda didn't give this game the true credit it deserved and that many people think it is just a ripoff of Fallout 3. But if you compare the two, it is night and day. Obsidian has a much greater knack for writing and a better grasp on the lore. It amazes me that a game like this can be made in just 18 months. But by God did they knock it out of the water. Many people wish for a Fallout New Vegas 2. But it isn't necessary. What they're really craving is for Bethesda to take their head out of their ass and create a game that has the fraction of love, care, and detail as this one. 
I legitimately think about this game throughout my day. I take the game out to dinner, maybe a walk in the park. One time I took the game to the roller rink and I fell down. But instead of making fun of me, Fallout New Vegas picked me up and we had a good laugh. This is the type of game I would take to meet my parents.

Still the gold standard of modern first person RPGs. A sandbox, open-world exploration based game where decisions matter and player agency and immersion are center focus. Graphically it sucks, its clunky, its old and dysfunctional without anti-crash mods, they only had like 4 voice actors but none of this matters once you uncover the core of the game. There aren't text walls of lore or convoluted mechanics for sake of having a steep learning curve. There's a sign north of Goodsprings with a skull on it, and you will die going that way on playthrough 1, but you can still choose to do it. You are never forced into anything for sake of story progression, "No" is always a dialogue option, and when it isn't, you can choose to either die or kill the person standing in front of you. The charm of this game is it's player agency and world tailored for exploration, there is almost nothing obscure or told in riddles that would leave a player wondering how to progress without consulting a wiki. It's enjoyable for several playthroughs, Ultimate edition is so cheap, its worth it.

The world Obsidian created is immersive, thought provoking, and never leaves you a dull moment. Every character is believable and lovable and the quests they send you on are always complex and rich with story building. I have lists of character RP and build ideas saved on top of the ones I have already completed. The DLC for this game is a masterclass in adding to the base content while also creating completely self-fulfilling stories. I wish this game was more accessible to new players so more could enjoy the once in a lifetime story and world New Vegas offers.

There is a running gag among me and my friends that once you have played this game there will be long periods where you must put it down. Once in a blue moon, however, something will call to you; you will return to the Mojave wasteland and question why you ever left.

Bethesda giving Obsidian a shot to work on their original brainchild with the some developers from Black Isle studios, who worked on fallout 2, was one of the best moves ever made for fans of not just Fallout but RPG's in general. Fallout New Vegas is a shining example of how to write a compelling story with choice and consequence. Top tier DLC content with robust play style choice has me coming back time and time again even after 14 years.

One of the better open world games. After playing over 100 hours on Xbox and over 45 hours on PC I can safely state this game is one of my top 10 favorites ever, and I would recommend it to anyone. Why?
-Fascinating and dynamic open world
-Extremely satisfying combat / crafting systems
-Engaging story with many interesting locations, people, and missions
-Cool music 
-Many useful and fun perks
-The ability to have up to 2 companions to act as body guards/ pack mules for your extra weapons/ supplies.
-Guaranteed fun!

Negatives about this game for me are: 
-Every choice matters, which is good, but there are so many possible outcomes that I end up overthinking many choices because doing a mission for one side may anger or at least slightly upset another side. There is a balance of who you are friends with and once you are against certain sides they send groups to ambush you, sometimes constantly, if you are a big enough enemy.
-The natural enemies such as Deathclaws and Cazadors are fun but there are a lot of them, and many enemies are OP. If you want a laid back type of game you will find yourself having to fight often.

Overall this game is a 9/10 for me!

One of the all-time great open-world action RPGs. My personal favourite Fallout game and it's not close. This is a classic.

After being shot in the head and left for dead, a courier sets out across the Mojave desert on the trail of their attempted killer. Once in New Vegas, their actions decide which of three factions (or themself) will win the Second Battle of Hoover Dam. In the process, they determine the fate of a whole host of every other faction and major character in the region.

There are a few things about New Vegas that might turn people off it. The looks. The gunplay. Inventory-management-Bethesda-game-vibes. A lot of slow walking until you've found location markers. Late-game quests encouraging a lot of fast travel. The crashes. Interiors that are repetitive to the point of being confusing to navigate. All of these are real problems. If you're the kind of person who needs these aspects to be great, then F:NV won't be for you.

But none of these problems should ruin the game for you. They're all pretty manageable. Just save a lot and enjoy the vibe. You'll get through it. I hear there are great mods for all of these.

The good aspects of New Vegas are exceptional and more than make up for the unsatisfying. They are the atmosphere, the open-ended narrative structure, the setting and the characters.

The atmosphere is masterfully created through soundscapes. The creatures and guns sound fine, but there are some exceptionally lonely non-music soundscapes that turn up when you turn your radio off. Unparalleled. 

The open-ended narrative structure of New Vegas is a masterpiece of art and engineering. It kind of boggles my mind that anyone could even make this. You can pick up quests any part of the way through and finish them in many different ways. The game never stops you from killing an important character. And this works at the micro- and macro- level. You can not just do individual quests in many ways, you can choose completely different main quests, which can open up or lock off other quests. You can kill Caesar without being asked and the game keeps going. In one of my play-throughs the president of the main faction got assassinated off stage. Next play-thorugh, I was in that faction's good books and I saved him from assassination. It's hard to put into words how reactive New Vegas is, but it really does feel like you can tackle any problem in a huge number of ways, and the game takes that into account.

What makes the setting great? It's not the visuals but the coherence and groundedness of it all. Characters mention locations, and things that have happened at them. And you can go and see those places for yourself. Everywhere you go (outside of Caesar's legion, which in my view having not played for them yet is a little less developed), you can see where people get their food and what they do for a living and so on. The battle lines make sense. It hangs together.

And the characters are all thoroughly solid. There are some standouts like Mr House, Joshua Graham/The Burned Man, No-Bark, Tabitha, and most of your companions (I love angry Boone). Like the setting, the important characters feel deeply realised, like a lot of thought has been put into how they became who they are and what they want.

All in all I thoroughly recommend New Vegas. An exceptional game. One of the classics.

Coming back to this game to make a review - used to had hundreds of hours on Xbox 360, and got this a few years back on PC just to experience it with mods.

Leaving this review after seeing Starfield got obliterated for sticking with Creation Engine, and this is a shining example of the single best game made in Creation by a long shot, carried by dialogues and great missions alone.

You have in-depth and intriguing sociopolitical commentary with all the factions of the world, you have well thought out personal story of a cast of characters with solid motivation and valid ideologies. All the missions and locations shared complex interconnecting narrative and world building, where all major events and decisions in the past of the world has an effect on physical and psychological outcome on a location. 

They built this in a short time of 8 months. They built the best western ARPG in a cave with a box of scraps.

If you need proof that Bethesda Studio clearly is living in a bubble and lack any form of awareness of what they're making, you don't have to look at Starfield - Fallout 4 completely thrown everything Obsidian got right with their engine in NV away and that should've set some alarm off for people.

While reading the reviews for this game you might as well be reading the reviews for Chrono Trigger, which is equally plagued by nostalia-clouded fools. This game sucks, bottom line is the base game is missing content, your character is worthless to the the entire game, the factions are just Pepsi vs Coke, and the ending is as rewarding as Mass Effect 3's--none of your choices matter and it's basically choose your Instagram Filter and Voiceover(s).

I wrote my first review after playing ten hours of the game, eight of which was spent trying to get it to work because it kept crashing.
The response of the overly-rabid fanbase was that I had not "played the game" and therefore my opinion was invalid.

Well guess what? I played your crappy game, forty hours of my total playtime was spent trying to fix the damn thing too.
I played this entire crappy game, and I did all the crappy missions either on PC or 360--because apparently consoles are the master race to play Fallout: New Vegas on.

This game sucks. It's incredibly empty of enemies even on very hard, there's zero interaction between NPCs unless you install Mods, 90% of the game is difficult to pass without exploiting the game or yourself so you're forced to meet the two game's factions (which I could never give a shit about (Pepsi VS Coke IMO)), and at no point do they explain who your character was prior to the game or why you should give a crap about them--unless you buy the DLC. Oh how we don't make fun of Todd Howard for making you fools buy the game twice.

Fans say you should make your own story. If that's the case how does the DLC fit for that shitfest geniuses? Your entire backstory is there for you--but only if you're willing to pay for it?! What kind of EA Paywall/Assassin's Creed Brotherhood bullshit is this? Why am I being told to make my own backstory and character when one season pass later I can learn it at my own leisure for the low price of $60--the same price of Skyrim in 2011--that will tell you your character's backstory as part of the main game?

The only enjoyment I got out of the base game was when I was finally done with the last quest and got the sweet satisfaction of killing every character in every town. I didn't use godmode, or kill all, no I didn't use console commands until the DLC, which I will talk about later. I used every gun, weapon, and bullet in my arsenal to murder everyone. I even installed mods so I could kill everyone. Base game factions are dog crap, no memorable Base Game NPCs, let's move onto the DLC.

Honest Hearts: The worst, don't even buy it.
Dead Money: My favorite DLC, only part of the game I enjoyed, so much story and detail. Super sad I can't revisit it without console commands and it tried to force me to Sophie's Choice at the end for things I could just tgm for.
Old World Blues: Boring, Dr. Venture was awesome but I couldn't stand that DLC. Everyone talked constantly, it's like the one part of the game where everyone doesn't play Mime Simulator and they overdid it.
Lonesome Road: Biggest letdown in history. You have three fucking DLC's two of them sucking the mightiest nut out of the third one's dick, hyping it up to be the second coming of christ. Then you play it and it's a straight walk while some robot and an asshole with a gas mask talk your ear off the whole time about shit that I couldn't care less about BECAUSE I MADE MY OWN STORY LIKE NOSTALGIC IDIOTS SAY YOU SHOULD. 
Actually, that's a lie; I liked the Robot, it repaired my gun for me once. All of this just so I could pump five rounds into Baine's face and kill a horde while nuking as many people as I could in the Mojave. What a thrill, five VATS shots and a dialog box, really glad you all told me "play lonesome road" when I said the game was recycled Fallout 3 assets without the courtesy of giving you the main character.

Mods:

Mods are honestly the only reason I played this hunk of garbage on PC. Aside from the fact I NEEDED them in order for the game to work--because why make a game that can work--Mods helped remind me that individuals are better at making content than Obsidian. After installing the three mods that helped the game not crash (as much) I finally installd a few to help make the game, you know, fun.

TL;DR the base game is garbage, the DLC is dumb, the mods are great because Obsidian didn't have the opportunity to fuck those up.
Don't play this game UNLESS you're playing Fallout 3 with the Tale of Two Wastelands mod, otherwise you're just some asshole passing through with a past that's hidden behind a paywall. You idiots need to stop fetishizing games just because they are in the desert and let you play wearing a cowboy hat. Cowboy hats do not a good game make.

1/5 - I really wanted to like this game, but same as in real life, I don't enjoy steaming piles of crap. The setting is in one of the most interesting places in the Fallout Universe and somehow Obsidian found a way to make it boring! I would only recommend the game if it's included in a bundle, the only reason I own it is because the fallout bundle doesn't let you line-item void this game from your purchase. I'd honestly pay steam to remove it from my library, but thankfully that's free.

Even if I think this game warrants more than one play trough, what I've already played and finished, it's more than enough that in spite of all it's flaws, whether technical or engine wise, this is one of the first games I think really takes advantage that it is an open world, guided at times, but the freedom it offers its like no other I've seen, this also extends to the perks system and the many ramifications that it opens, having played a bit of Fallout 3 already, this game just puts Bethesda to shame, even more impressive for its short development time.

Don't really wanna spoil much in terms of your choices since I think its better to go blind, but this game allows for a character build that you really have to commit over time, which I personally like, give's the whole "role playing" of the Fallout series some actual weight instead of just being a generic shooter that just so happens to be set in an apocalypse, the moral choices in regards to the factions really make you think at times, which I'm surprised ended up being so effective, one thing I rarely feel in games is immersion, and New Vegas knocks it out of the park with it's world building, the endings are also really satisfying, actually reflecting the choices you made on the journey.

By my wording it would seem the game is perfect, but I do have some red flags that I'm really guessing might turn away some people, the technical issues of this game are just ridiculous at times, constant crashing, corrupted save files, broken missions, broken AI, constant freezing at loading screens, unstable frame rate, overall jittery movement, and many many bugs. I had to deal with so many issues in my play trough and almost lost all my progress to a corrupted save file because of the crashing, but I personally think it is kinda worth it to endure it just to platy this game, it is that good, just a little warning flag to people who might not know the state of this game, aside from that, just fantastic, def my fav open world game I've played.

This game elicits strong and varied reactions, and it's worth noting that achieving stable and optimal performance may necessitate modding. In my personal experience, integrating mods has significantly reduced the occurrence of crashes. Similar to other Bethesda games, the true potential of this game is most evident when complemented by its dedicated modding community, which stands out for the exceptional quality of mods and their transformative impact on the game. Additionally, the core storyline offers multiple branching paths, distinguishing it from the likes of Fallout 3 or Fallout 4. This multifaceted narrative foundation, in my view, provides a more solid framework for expansion, as no amount of modding can compensate for a lackluster story.
really good game not better than fallout 3 but still really good game

To be clear, this game has a great story; Fallout: New Vegas boasts a truly compelling narrative. If you can find it at a good price, it's worth the investment, and I don't regret my purchase since I paid $2.49. However, in my opinion, this game is massively overrated; it's known as one of the better RPGs. I got it for my winter break from the last semester to pass the time. I encountered around 100 crashes or so, and my game would frequently stutter during combat, despite having an Intel i9 and a practically brand-new system. It would crash out of the game every 45 minutes to an hour during a play session.

I have 60 hours of in-game time, according to Fallout, but according to Steam, it's 80 hours. This discrepancy is due to all the times I crashed and rebooted the game, wasting a significant amount of time—essentially, an entire day of my life waiting for this game to load. Seriously, avoiding it will save you a day of your life. If you're desperate enough, either watch a YouTube playthrough of this game. the gameplay was mediocre; I wasn't impressed. I thought I would use V.A.T.S. more, but my character build made it frustrating. You walked around as slow as dirt, and exploring became boring. I got to the point where I would fast travel and be done with it. In other games, I don't like fast travel, just not in this game; it came in real handy because you're slow as molasses, and there were some quests that would make you think, which was good. I'm not that good at those sorts of things, but I respect it, though it got to the point where it was a bit rage-inducing.

Again, the branching paths and the ability to create your own story were interesting, especially considering when this came out, it was difficult to do that back then, and still, many game studios don't allow you to create your own story. This game is supposed to be better regarding crashes now, but I can't imagine playing any other Fallout game, as this was my first and only Fallout game I will ever play because I know these games get worse from here.
