[h2]Disclaimer:[/h2]
This review based on my multiple playthrough spanning from Vanilla (unmodded) game to bug-fixed and modded game. My review based on my own opinion without reinforcement of external party (community, other player etc.). However my review address the vanilla experience since it's what most player going to get, unless stated below.
[hr][/hr]

Fallout New Vegas. What happen when you brought Fallout 2 (expanded) into 3D space which offers countless replayability and Role playing that beloved by its Fanbase. The Vanilla experience is kind of okay but once you learn modding on this game, it offer limitless possibility of enjoyment of Western Role Playing genre.

[h2]Gameplay:[/h2]
Just like its predecessor Fallout 3, New Vegas offer real time combat and VATS mode that helps you aiming limbs of your enemy. On this installment the combat more varied and every build like melee, unarmed, heavy weapons, energy weapons are equal in term of balancing, you can make them overpowered too if you can build your character right on their respective disciplinary focus. Unarmed and Melee build kind of close to Fallout 2 in term of its overpowered-ness once you get proper perks and build.

Perhaps due to several original Interplay staffs, the writing on this game is superior compared to Fallout 3 although the trade off is the world-visual storytelling that excels in Fallout 3 is less prominent in New Vegas.

New to this game is Faction Rep which more or less "it is works", if only it can be expanded further (but as we know the development time is pretty tight on this game).

DT and DR is back on this game instead of only relying Damage Resistance in Fallout 3. In my opinion using DT and DR is make more sense like in classic Fallout considering "Armor" can be divided into clothings and armors which have its own level of protection.

Ammo type is back from classic Fallouts. This mechanics brings better variety of combat as you're more likely using AP ammo on thick-skinned creatures or heavily armored enemies to punch through its armor's DT instead of using your standard ammo. Surplus is great choice if you want to get cheap ammos, (some types) have better armor penetration, though the trade off is your weapon would wear faster due to lower grade of its quality.

[h2]Storyline/Writing:[/h2]
I like how an afterthought character could shape the whole New Vegas thematic to full circle. A History, to let go and begin again (the past and future).

Through memes, time, and anything else perhaps everyone already know the plot.
You're Mailman who ordered to bring a special package into the heart of New Vegas, then suddenly you're hijacked mid-way and then the rest is there.

This game has lots reference to Fallout 1 and Fallout 2 considering New Vegas also take place closer to West Coast, even you can find some characters from Fallout 2 in here.

Side quests are fun too and varied though if you're rushing the game, you would probably miss lots of unmarked quest that really hidden gem of this game.

Dialogue choice is more diverse and skill checks is more prominent compared to Fallout 3.

for DLCs, my opinion such as below:
- Dead Money feels intimidating to newcomer because you're stripped on the start of DLC gameplay, navigating villa can be overwhelming if it's your first time. Once you understand and familiar with the DLC you're going to play this one breeze. Also decapitate those Ghost people. The writing and backstory is between okay and decent, but the most sought after of this DLC is the gold bars at the end of DLC, make your choice!

- Old World Blue, this one probably the [i]hardest[/i] DLC because there is an oversight by the developer that force the spawned NPC to be same level as you in Vanilla. The enemies can be bullet sponge though you can dispose them easily if you have snipers/Stealth crit kill. You can play this game real fast (heck on my latest playthrough I accidentally finished it under 3 hour) or more slower to explore Big MT.

- Honest Heart, bit of weak compared to the rest of storyline DLC. However this DLC visit some backstory of the lore in New Vegas and expands the existing one that also complement for the final DLC. Zion park feel fresh (no pun intended) compared to other DLC world map.

- Lonesome Road, decent DLC that have excellent character. Though I'd rather take this DLC as the last one to play because I felt it is more fitting for being the last (in timeline, and more info resource from previouses DLCs).

[h2]Sound Design:[/h2]
Hmm, sound design is not bad that bad yet also not great.

[h2]Graphics Design:[/h2]
Graphics is similar to Fallout 3 though on this game you have Piss filter on because it's desert. Maxed graphics level felt decent for move but if you want to have better graphics, use mods that remove that tinted filter, better weather and nice Reshade presets (for a note do not use ENB unless your graphics is powerful and it's not 2013 too).

[h2]Control Design:[/h2]
Same as Fallout 3, sometimes when you're doing movement you may be bugged. Menu navigation can be improved with mods.

[h2]Difficulty:[/h2]
Kind of forgot vanilla difficulty but if you want to stay reasonable, use Normal difficulty. Higher difficulty only affect DMG taken from NPC and dealt from Player. On Hardcore Mode difficulty does not change that much only you have added stats like human Needs (Hunger, Water, and Sleep) and Added weight for ammos.

[h2]Overall:[/h2]
Since this game also byproduct of its era and buggy Gamebyro game engine (carried from Fallout 3), this game can be buggy without bug fixes and script addons.

For that, I would rate this game 8/10 though if you want to mod it, this game easily have same similar level of enjoyment like modded Skyrim.

[h2]Personal Note:[/h2]
For a starter, You may want to use Viva New Vegas guide up to bug fixes for pure vanilla experience. then if you want first taste of modded game, try Viva New Vegas Extended+ guide.

If you want to enjoy Fallout New Vegas just as intended by one of the designer (Joshua E Sawyer) try JSawyer tweak-type mods to alter your gameplay. While some people consider this tweak can be crude in term of balancing, I think the re-balance that have been done by JESawyer is make sense as it forces you to become more resourceful on items, planning ahead to move, and use every features from New Vegas offer (eg. Mailboxes, Campfire). I recommend to use JSUE as it does not alter dramatically from the original tweak mod vision.

The best game I've played thus far. Allows a large amount of choice for the player and allows for serious ethical discussion. It manages to simultaneously capture the feel of Fallout 3 whilst also maintaining an older, RPG style to it. No decision in Fallout: New Vegas is easy, and players are habitually asked to make genuinely tough and challenging decisions.

Note, however, the game's propensity to crash often. It's thirteen years old as I write, and so this is to be expected. However, the game makes it worth it. Even if you must quicksave frequently to prevent losing progress, you do get a game of this calibre, and only a game such as this would make frequent crashes worth it.

Not gonna sugarcoat anything here, this is the most scuffed game I've ever played. Stutters, bugs, crashing, it's a mess, and it is sad because at the same time, it is one of the best games I have ever played. The presentation, dialogue, combat, this game has nearly everything. Sometimes I feel bad that, it was more of a me problem than the game itself, because being the busy guy as I am, I'm glossing it over how good this game really is.

If you really want this game to work, if you truly want it to run the way it should and reach for the optimal state it should be played in, then yes, what you have is a gem polished to perfection nearly forgotten in the decade's time. If you have the time, maybe you can enjoy it, much more than I expected that I would.

I recommend this game, even if I am sad to find out, it isn't for a guy like me, and even if I like it so much.

This game is a classic in my eyes with hours and hours of replayaility. One of the greatest entries in the Fallout franchise. There are so many versions of the player you can create and so many routes to go throughout the game. I've played through this game at LEAST 5 times at this point and it never gets old for me. The only issues I have to hark on are the obvious crashes you'll experience from time to time. Make sure you're saving every so often in case it happens to you. I've heard of mods that help with that but I've never bothered with them. It honestly isn't enough of a problem to have to searching for them just a bit annoying. With the DLCs added it adds even more replayability. Almost a whole new game with all of them added.

Best Fallout game, I would recommend getting some mods, but it's good with the vanilla experience also. Here's some things I like about it:

The feeling of tangible progress, the detail put into all the NPCs, how obsidian somehow managed to make a very good open world experience that is relatively similar to the Bethesda ones (World design, art direction, etc.), and of course the writing and role playing options are absolutely god tier.

There are flaws to the base game, however. The game-play has aged somewhat, but it's more fun than Fallout 3 and almost as good as Fallout 4. The game can also be extremely glitchy, which is my main issue with it.

However, it is still an insanely great game. I would give it a 9.3/10.

Okay so i keep seeing a lot of negative reviews about the crashing so I'ma give a suggestion.
Only for Windows 10 cause i font have any other OS so i wouldn't know
Go to bottom left of screen click the windows sign, click settings, click system, click about, click advanced system settings and there will be a pop up, click settings on the performance part and a second pop up will show, then click on advanced and finally click on change under virtual memory(It just changes the paging file size that acts like pseudo RAM) and set it to a pretty high number(It's in MB so multiply by a thousand for GB), this worked for me but I have no Idea if it'll work for everyone.

As to why it might work, my best guess has to do with F:NV's memory leak issue, since you are adding pseudo RAM I'm guessing it essentially acts like putting a bucket under a leak, not really fixing the problem but delaying it for a long time, longer than you're using it.

Frankly i can't recommend this game enough. I own three copies of it on various platforms and am happy to have started replaying the game yet again. I started a new playthrough a few weeks ago and i'm loving my time. Despite having several hundred hours on my xbox, and another 100+ here, i can confidently say i'm still loving this game more then 13 years after it was released. While it certainly misses some features of newer and more modern games, it's still one of my favorite narrative experiences and i can't resist playing the game again at least once a year. At only 20 dollars for the game and all it's dlc on steam, it's a downright steal. As of writing it's the steam winter sale for 6.59 usd, about a third of it's retail price for the ultimate edition, which is damn near free. I will play this game for the rest of time, and keep playing it after time has ended.

My first playtrough of fallout new vegas was terrible, Ive had crashes every 15 minutes or so and I did not understand any part of the lore, and it ended in the save file corrupting and not even halfway finished. after i downloaded seventy hundred gajillion mods the game finally ran smoothly. My second playtrough of the game was okay. I couldnt immerse myself in the story too deeply because you dont uncover much of the history in a single playtrough, bit of a shame since the game's main selling point is the writing, as people say. Important details scattered on the different routes you can choose. After that I played trough fallout 1 and 2, then extensively reading the wiki for hours digging for lore, then finally everything opened up to me as I started understanding the things happening within the game. my third playtrough was the best run I had out of the three since I can immerse myself in the world and realize the consequences of the things I chose to do.
Still even after all of that I couldnt get myself to enjoy dead money after 2 times playing. it soured my mood every time I played it. I can go on but that would take too long
I can see why people would like the game but its not a perfect game people would tell you into believing. Play without too much expectation.

Fallout New Vegas is a game I've been told is worthwhile, considering I've played the two games worth playing, Dishonered and Metal Gear Rising, I knew it was up to me to determine whether or not this was an accurate statement. After thorough analysis I have come to the conclusion Fallout New Vegas is in fact one of the best RPG's ever made. There are plenty of places that can tell you this information however I will tell you about the evil publisher of this game.

Bethesda are a game studio and subsidiary to parent company that they split off from Zenimax Media, these companies have done a number of poopoo things, such as sell cosmetics in a single player rpg for 5 dollars, try to sell community made mods for monetary gain and resell the same game a dozen times. Needless to say I am shocked anyone buys games from these heathens but that's not all, they also out trans employees and then fire them while holding their healthcare hostage, they release horribly designed games that are shown up by decade old games they published (Yeah New Vegas) and consistently under perform while demanding players to tolerate their garbage business practices.

It is for these reasons I do not support buying this game through the digital store front, buy a copy from a third party or other means of acquisition that are legal and I am unaware of that do not involve this deplorable company that also didn't pay Oblivion who delivered us one of the greatest games of all time their bonuses because they missed 1 metacritic point score after giving them a shit deadline and budget to pump out a game with. Fuck Bethesda, Fuck Todd, Fuck Zenimax. Play good games and give good devs your money.

Fallout New Vegas is one of the best RPG's of all time. This game was handed to Obsidian from Bethesda and they had to make it in less than 2 years. In that context especially, this game is nothing short of incredible. Interesting main story along with a slew of amazing side quests, unique weapons and perks, fun and unique towns and factions, packaged with the vast lore and world of Fallout. There is a reason why this game is still played 13 years after release. Bethesda could only wish for a game like this, and after the blunder that was Starfield, they likely will never come close to this. The ego of Bethesda has already rejected Obsidian's offers to make more games in this universe, as well as the Elder Scrolls. What a shame. Play this game, and forget about Bethesda. 10/10

[h1][u]A Struggle Between Nostalgia and Modern Standards[/u][/h1]
Approaching 'Fallout New Vegas' years after its release, I was met with a clash between my expectations, built by its strong reputation, and the reality of dated game mechanics.

[b][u]Pro:[/u][/b]
+ ...

[b][u]Contra:[/u][/b]
- Gameplay feels clumsy and outdated, not living up to modern gaming standards.
- Disappointment stems not from the game's content or story, but from its obsolete mechanics.
- The experience is marred by the struggle to adapt to the game's aging systems.

[b][u]Conclusion:[/u][/b]
While 'Fallout New Vegas' has a celebrated status in gaming history, playing it for the first time 12 years after its release left me feeling let down. The game, sadly, feels [u]BAD[/u] due to its outdated mechanics, overshadowing its otherwise intriguing aspects. A remake might one day revive its magic, but for now, it's a challenge to enjoy in its original form.

I've had a long time to appreciate New Vegas. Like many great works, it's quality only becomes more apparent with time. This could be the best writing in the industry.

The community is still debating the ethics of the factions and their power struggle. It's not hyperbole to say that NV has enriched its audience and forces them to expand their perspective the more they consider it.

One of the characters in this game is religious, yet is so well written he's developed a reputation for converting nonbelievers into Christians, IRL. Torn in quite a literal way between the old and new testament, between fire within, the fire around, and the waters of forgiveness.

Another would otherwise be a typical fascist dictator, yet presents his case so earnestly and with such justification that it takes some serious minded reading to find its flaws. Yet even at the end, it would make perfect sense for his knowledge of Hegelian dialectics to be skewed given his background.

Another is a man drowning in perspective, having traveled and seen too much with such contradiction he can't form the through-line that ties it all together. His passing and goings are spoken of through the whispers of others long before you meet him. His enigma is a shadow cast on a long and lonesome road.

Another is a ghost of the old world, eyes set forward  to such a lofty horizon that he doesn't care to see who lies beneath it. I'm telling you, hearing his "Democracy" line for the first time had me staring out my own window for a good while before I sat back down. Prepare to have your assumptions challenged.

New Vegas is easily the best of the best in the Fallout franchise. The story, the characters, the interactions, everything. This is one of those games that I consider almost perfect, it has everything.
Pros:
-The combat is incredible, almost every weapon feels great to use, guns and energy weapons have great sound design, you can feel the weight of your attacks with melee and unarmed. 
-The setting is incredible, the mojave wasteland is full of interesting places and characters to interact with. Just in Vegas alone you can finish a playthrough and still find new stuff in your next one.
-The interactions are top notch, characters react to things that have happened in the past. They know who you are and what you have done in your playthrough. There's always new lines of dialogue to find in the game depending on the way you approach a quest.

Cons:
-I can only think of one, but it's a really big one: the compatibility. If you run fallout new vegas right after you buy it, it's very likely to crash after a few minutes of gameplay. The game isn't very compatible with newer operating systems and it can be very annoying to lose 15-20 minutes of progress because the game crashed and you didn't save. If you plan on playing vanilla, SAVE OFTEN. I started playing this game a long time ago and I never finished it because the crashes were really bad. It wasn't until last year when I decided to give the game another chance and now I love it. On the other hand, if you want the crashes to stop or at least be minimal, mods are the way to go. I personally run Viva New Vegas, it's a modlist you can download (almost) automatically with a sotware called Wabbajack. The site is super friendly and it guides you through the installation step by step. You can even disable some mods if you don't want all of them when you're done.
Buy it on GOG. Much easier to tweak and mod

One of my favourite games, possibly my number 1. What more is there to say about FNV that hasn't been said already? It's considered a beloved (if flawed and janky) classic/masterpiece for a reason. Similar to an amazing Granddad - it's joints are stiff, it's not going to win any prizes for good-looks, and sometimes you really feel how outdated some aspects of it are. However, all that being said; it has some amazing stories, filled with truly memorable characters and moments. It's charm is undeniable and the world of FNV is one I wholeheartedly recommend exploring. I would urge you to spend a bit of time (depending on your familiarity/competence with modding...Setting things up could take you 30mins or a few hours, as you may - as I did, need to watch some tutorials etc. to get everything set up correctly, or simply to identify what mods you would like). Installing a few mods, at the very least some quality of life/performance based ones! It's honestly very simple once you understand/get over the fear of extracting files etc. but the Vortex mod manager will help a tonne! (There are some great tutorials out there). To conclude, this game is a must for any lover of RPGs (True RPGs, not shallow adventure-based games with RPG mechanics slapped on...looking at you Bethesda, but now is not the time to vent my perpetual frustration regarding THAT company). I love this game, not only for being a truly incredible journey, but also for keeping me occupied during a very difficult time in my life. From a far, FNV may look old, unattractive and stiff (It did when it came out over a decade ago tbf haha), but I promise, by the time you catch your first glimpse of the glowing city...of New Vegas, you will already be entangled in a beautiful Obsidian web. Unable to free yourself from it's embrace and unable to find a reason why you would want to. What message will you bring forth to the Mojave and what will you leave in your wake? Play it again...Johnny...Guitar <3

It's been said time and time again, but I can wholeheartedly assert that this is not only the singular best RPG to date, but one of the most well-crafted and brilliant games of all time. As long as you can stand the lower-end graphics, which in general contribute to the overall ingenious style of the game, this is one of the most incredible gaming experiences I've ever had. The story is rich and fulfilling, with nearly every minute decision you make affecting how the plot plays out. The map is rather large, with many different landmarks scattered around the Mojave Desert that contribute to the lore and story behind the world. Not to mention the NPC interactions which are all almost perfectly done, with every new character you come across having a unique and creative backstory that impacts how you interact with them. And for 10 dollars, and 2 dollars on sale, this game is worth every single penny. I'm writing this having only played this Fallout game, and I am planning to purchase Fallout 3 and 4 later this year. From what I have read online, I have somewhat spoiled myself with this game, but hopefully Bethesda delivers on the others as well.

Fallout New Vegas is the best thing Bethesda and Zenimax has yet to create . Graphically sure its no Starfield but as we all should know "looks aren't everything"  . It's not totally hideous it just shows its age . The characters and story  other than being shot in the head more than make up for it. A modicum of actual role playing goes so far . Much better than the chosen one dragon born super power starfield powers crap . Yhe NCR and Ceaser  are way better than the minute men or the stupid maked no sense lets save synths by blowing up the institute railroad will or could ever be .  The reveals are much better . The few plot twist are good and much less predictable then Oblivion or Skyrim .          ...    This game has actual edge .  It is the LAST Bethesda game to have anything even approximating mature content .     Everything after has been rated G in comparison .  The fact that the slot machines actually work and luck and gambling can really affect your early game is just wonderful .  No other Bethesda game especially Crap field  has such depth tho the companions not to mention the likeability .  Elderscroll games have yet fo have even one memorable companion . I can't name one .   ..The choices in this game are the best and most far reaching of any title in the Fall out universe .  The voice acting especially of Mr. House and Cassidy are very well done and believable.  The fun and the balance of combat is very good and sniping and stealth seemed just right for me . All the giant abandoned buildings and sites made sense and had purpose and you find more than just another sword or pipe pistol your just gonna drop or sell .   .. The bad guys in this world just really need a good killin . Whereas is in copy field I just can't care about the starborn or what they want or what they are doing .  Same for the thieves guild or the assassins  etc. etc .  I would just as well see them succeed at what the hell ever their lame little meaningless goals are . Mr. New Vegas is great way better than lame ole Travis .  Bethesda got rid of or dumbed down all the things that make this game great or just simply never understood them or just got lucky . Either way this game works "it just works " .  Too bad about the mods or the lack there of though . There are a handful of okay ones but no where near enough .

Fallout New Vegas is unlike any game I've ever played. I want to say it's like Skyrim or Oblivion or even the other Fallouts, but it's not really. It's in a league of its own. The story is brutally deadpan and the choices you have to make are usually neutrally chaotic. It really just pulls you in and you find yourself caring for these digital people and you don't even know why. On the flip side, when you meet your enemies (who you will choose), you will hate them to the CORE! There is a lot of side questability to this game. You really don't have to follow any sort of linear progression, short of just GETTING to Vegas. Although if you want to brave the north right away and think you can tango with some death crawlers, there really is no linear anything to the opening of the map. Bottom line, I love this game. It will suck you in, immerse you and not let go. It's playable multiple times from the beginning especially if you want to take a different path. You want to be a psycho killer or do you want to be the savior of the waste? Maybe you just want to be Jimmy Neutral, or a big mix of all. It's all up to you. Enjoy.

Okay so here is reasons for you not to play

 • Very buggy and can be very unstable with sometimes your saves not working and losing progress (can be fixed with mods)
 • Bad gun play (outside of its auto targeting system) and enemy ai 
 • Boring colour scheme (so little green so much orange and bad face models could hurt immersion if you can't deal with bad graphics  
 • Alot of the places you see on the map you can't actually go (mountains that are you cannot traverse) 
 • Bad face models could hurt immersion if you can't deal with bad graphics 

Reasons to play
 • Brilliant story in which you can side with a billionaire from before the bombs fell who wants to help restore Vegas to its former glory, the new Californian republic a attempt on rebuilding america and Caesars legion the new Rome who like to do slavery sexism and war crimes and are just evil in general but you can still join them 
 • You like branching quest lines and amazing world building 
 • So many perks to help you build the perfect character multiple paythroughs may be required though to make a truly great character
 • Immersive world building and amazing characters 
• Great soundtrack 
• A lot of memorable moments 

To end the review great game definitely overrated but still a amazing game and if there were no bugs it would be around a must play nine out of ten but because it has those issues i sadly have to give seven but if you like rpgs and immersive worlds and don't mind a lot of bugs and crashes get it

Fallout: New Vegas stands as a testament to the triumph of storytelling and player choice over the limitations of its development process. Created in a relatively short development cycle and built on an engine that, at the time, was less than ideal, this game overcame significant challenges to become a beloved classic.

During its creation, the game faced hurdles due to the limitations of the engine it was built upon. The engine, while serviceable, presented numerous technical issues and constraints that the development team had to navigate. It's noteworthy that at the time of the game's creation, few developers truly grasped the intricacies of the GECK engine, making the task even more daunting.

Despite these challenges, Fallout: New Vegas shines brightly in its narrative depth and player-driven storytelling. The game's narrative, filled with intricate choices and consequences, remains one of its strongest aspects. The intricate web of factions, morally ambiguous decisions, and branching storylines offers players a level of agency rarely found in open-world RPGs.

Moreover, the world-building and atmosphere crafted within the constraints of the engine are commendable. The desolate yet vibrant Mojave Wasteland feels alive with its unique characters, varied landscapes, and engaging quests. The dedication of the developers to work around the engine's limitations to create such a rich and immersive world is evident at every turn.

Despite its technical shortcomings at launch, the modding community played a pivotal role in enhancing and refining the gaming experience. Fan-made patches and mods have not only fixed many of the initial issues but also expanded the game's potential, showcasing the passion and dedication of the community.

Fallout: New Vegas, while born from a tumultuous development environment, remains a testament to the resilience of its creators and the enduring appeal of a well-crafted narrative. Its legacy lives on not just through its flaws, but through the remarkable storytelling and player agency that continue to captivate gamers even years after its release.

Fallout New Vegas is a good entry point to the Fallout series as a whole. If I could ever name a game that I could confidently say that I grew alongside with, it's definitely this game. Having played the game since 2011 on the Xbox 360 and moved over to PC with countless of play throughs, every single run is a definitive experience. New Vegas is pretty simple to mod and you can easily make the game look up and feel to today's gaming standards, but even then there is a certain appeal to the vanilla experience that many of us die hard fans keep going back to.

You may have heard that this game has great humor, and that is true, especially if you get the Wild Wasteland trait; however, even if you don't get that trait you're mostly just missing out on pop culture references and a unique weapon with limited available ammo (which can fixed with mods), so if you don't like that kind of stuff just skip over that trait since most of the actual humor is in the interactions with the npcs and dialogue.

SPOILERS: The major factions all want the same thing but the key difference between all of them is how they want to accomplish that goal, and it's up to you to decide which option you like best. First there's Mr. House who wants a technocratic autocracy that thrives as it has been before the NCR and Caesar's Legion showed up. Yes Man just wants to give the Mojave to whoever's giving him order's (conveniently that's you). The NCR wants to bring "democracy" (interpreted as bureaucracy). Lastly, Caesar's Legion wants to rule over the Mojave with an iron fist.

The variety of weapons available in the game surpasses even Fallout 3 and I think Fallout 2, and it's the only game I know of that has grenade machine guns. On top of that, there's the ammo system that theoretically allows you to stick with one gun in all situations as long as you don't run out of ammo, although I haven't tested it because I have a hard time sticking with one weapon because there are so many with nice aesthetics.

I won't get to much into the perks and traits, but I will say that it offers plenty of variety in your build choice even if there are some basic options that you'll pick no matter what.

One of the best Fallout games in the series, offering unmatched story telling and narrative in the classic Fallout universe. I don't think any other Fallout game compares in experience besides perhaps the first or second ones in the genre. This is a must-play if you are a fan of Bethesda's fallout series.

In every person's life, they are often asked the question "What's you favorite video game?". Some may anwser with a veritably popular title, or an old school classic, or say that their tastes lie more in a genre of games rather than a single one. But for me, New Vegas is, bar none, my singular favorite game I own.

What can I say that the legion of other reviews, videos, and online posts haven't said about it? Praising the characters and story, that make the Mojave Wasteland feel alive and makes you feel like your character has an impact on the story? That Obsidian added a much appreciated depth to the mechanics, from survival to manufacturing ammunition to the companions, and so much more? The even with it being pretty buggy even for Obsidian and Bethesda standards it's still worth playing (especially so with mods to fix and enhance it)? There's so much that's already been said, so let me just explain why I love it: immersive replayablity.

In a lot of other games, heck a lot of other Fallouts, it's hard to sometimes make a build or keep to the spirit of who your character should be. Even if you play as a melee master in Fallout 3, a scourge upon the wasteland with blood and death in your blade and fists, your both reminded by the story that you're mostly just a son looking for his lost father and by the mechanics that don't support much melee skills. 

But in New Vegas? Get the right gear and you can cosplay as your own wasteland warlord, and the perks add DEPTH to your playstyle: not just more damage, but perks that prevent you from being knocked down or cleaving through blocking enemies to name a few. Your whole playstyle can change depending on what you pick, and the next time you decide to replay the whole thing, awaking from being shot in the head twice, you can pick something else: a scientist that uses energy weapons, a hunter that sneaks and picks off enemies from afar... New Vegas gives you the tools to do this kind of stuff, and allows you to complete the game with it if you wish to.

That's just my two cents to it, at least. The game is 10 bucks, cheaper if on sale, though I'd recommend getting the Ultimate Edition to play through the excellent DLCs. Please do yourself a favor and get it; you'll have the time of your life if you do, and if you can learn how to mod it... well, the sky's the limit, mi amigo.

8 out of 10.

The good: Several little additions make this a worthy sequel to Fallout 3. You can modify your weapons with scopes and other enhancements, and you can make your own ammo with different characteristics such as armor piercing.  Furthermore this game comes with a hardcore mode where you have to sleep and eat! There is also a more fleshed out companion system than we had in Fallout 3. The Mojavi desert seems more alive and more populated than the DC area in Fallout 3, whether that is a good thing or not is up to you. All in all all the things that made Fallout 3 great are back in this game, including the entertaining perks that give the game replayability.

The bad: Although the game by no means looks bad, the engine is showing its age. Particularly the character models are not very pretty to look at. The sandbox nature of the game makes it often necessary to look online whether the person you just took out was part of a 8 parted quest.
Been playing this game since release on Xbox 360 and I have done basically everything you can do. Hands down the best Fallout game of all time, Obsidian is far superior to Bethesda!

Fallout: New Vegas has some of the best world-building, storytelling, and role-playing ever.

Your choices matter. There are plenty of ways to approach every situation, based on the skills you choose-- you can fight your way through enemies, sneak past them, bribe them to leave you alone, hack their security systems, or convince them with your words that fighting is not a good option. You can roleplay as a wide variety of characters that play diifferently.

The world is very detailed, and the story is a well-written clash of ideologies. In this game you run into plenty of interesting characters with lots to say, some of it thought-provoking, some of it funny.

Only downsides I can mention are bugs (in 150+ hours, I've had three crashes and one easily fixed mouse issue) and a slow start (you may find starting off kind of boring, but persevere and it will become great).

New Vegas is a work of art, but unlike most shitty "art" games, it's also actually fun.

The 364 hours at time of review don't cover the approximately 900 I had on the Xbox 360 before I got it on PC, honestly what can I say that hasn't been said a million times already? As far as the Bethesda formula goes, this was the pinnacle, bugs and all. I've come back a million and a half times and I still love every minute in this world. The mods add tons of life and nonsense, but the base game will always be something uniquely special. If ever a game was deserving of a faithful remaster, it's this one -- maybe in an engine without loading zones? But even the jank is endearing. 

Tl;dr, from the tutorial area the story is compelling, well laid out, you're corralled by skill gates you are entirely capable of learning to overcome, but until that point it guides you marvelously into one of the best written video game conflicts in the medium. It's one of the only games (that isn't a map painter/spreadsheet sim) that actually provides a compelling critique of the American system without being cringe and preachy, and actually does a reasonable job of presenting the 'bad guys' as a reasonable alternative -- even as the limited development time forced them to cut the majority of their depth and cartoonify them a bit. Even if it's not the deepest, it still provides compelling moral quandries, and meditations on what the best good for the future really looks like. 

The gameplay is a blast, VATS may have grown old in later titles but it's still a load of fun in it's original iteration (once you learn the quirks). Weapon upgrading is fun without being overbearing, and the weapons themselves are largely realistic in their function (a skill Bethesda would then immediately and permanently lose). Obsidian put in the work not just on a good story, but a well-formed world with a lot of secrets, niches, and charm. And the DLC? All of it shines in some way. 

Honest hearts is the weakest in setting and gameplay, but the characters, specifically Joshua Graham, are deeply compelling. Dead Money is a pain in a sense, but treated like an entirely different game it is a fun experience learning to survive and getting mileage out of your oft-neglected survival skill. Old World Blues is the fan favorite, a bit too reddit lolsorandom ebin rick and morty science for my tastes now, but as a kid I loved it as much as anyone else. It has a lot of fun ideas and writing, it's just a shame it became everyone's baby and the other DLCs came in underformed as a result. Finally Lonesome Road is a fantastic capstone to the story, forcing you to confront your amnesiac past and the failings of everyone in the wasteland, providing a grim look at what could be the end for everyone. All worth playing, all a good time. I just love this game so much, it wasn't until Baldur's Gate 3 I found another game that quite scratched the escapism itch like this. 10/10

So many people seem to think a pound of feathers and a pound of steel weigh the same but this is not true and is the kind of ♥♥♥♥ you should have learned in primary and secondary schools.

Lets start with the basics.

Mass: It also tells you how much "stuff" is in it. Now by stuff I kind of mean atoms and molecules but different atoms and molecules do not weigh the same, so the amount of "stuff" is dependent on the thing we are talking about. It is also a measurement of inertia, which is an object resistance to acceleration (or deceleration). Units to measure mass include but are not limited grams, pounds, tons, kilograms, stones, etc.

Volume: How much room something takes up (3-d space) units include (cubic centimeters, cubic meters, liters, etc)

Density: Mass of an object per given unit of volume this can be found by dividing mass by the volume it occupies. (g/L which is a gram per liter, could also be gram per cubic centimeter,)

Gravity: Caused by mass, all mass exerts a gravitational pull. the more mass the more "gravity" it will have. Gravity is a constant pretty much every where on earth, it does decrease as you increase in altitude by it is negligible, even if you were to stand on top of mount Everest there isn't too much of a difference with the acceleration due to gravity being 9.77 m/s/s, so its negligible unless you are talking about extreme masses, but this difference is not important to the subject at hand

Velocity: Your displacement per unit of time(i.e. seconds)

Speed: Distance per unit of time (i.e. seconds)

Force: I am not talking about Star Wars force, I am talking about physics force. A vector, the product of mass and acceleration, and I mean it literally, multiply mass and acceleration and you get force. Now, gravity causes an acceleration so your "weight" is technically a force caused by the gravity of Earth which in free fall accelerates you by 9.8 m/s/s (9.8 meters per second per second), meaning you speed up by 9.8 meters per second every second. The unit for this is Newtons in Metric and pounds, the imperial units are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ stupid when it comes to force cause there is stones, pounds (which is also what they use for mass), and slugs and some other ♥♥♥♥, I am not going to use them)

Momentum: A product of mass and velocity, found by multiplying mass and velocity.

Now lets get into this, a kilogram of one this is going to have the exact same mass as a kilogram of another thing. Lets look at water and "air" for example. Mass is a measurement of how much stuff is in something and density tells you how much stuff is in something per unit of volume (so you could say how packed in the stuff is per unit of volume). Water is a lot more dense (meaning there is more stuff per given unit of volume, or it is more "concentrated") than air, so you will need less water in terms of volume to get a kilogram than you would air (we are talking about air at at sea level pressure).

Now since they have the same mass they will have the same weight, since gravity is essentially is a constant at any given altitude on Earth, the water and the air will have the same weight because they have the same mass and because gravity is the same. Therefore they would press down on the Earth with the same force as well. So lets go with a scenario of you are holding the objects. To make this example easier to understand lets do this. Lets say we have two boxes that are the same size with no mass, they also don't bend or stretch. Now lets say in one you put in the kilogram of water into it and in the other box you put the 1 kilogram of air into it. Now there is 1 kilogram of stuff air in once box and 1 kilogram of water in another. So now you go to pick up the boxes, they both have 1 kg (kilogram) of mass inside them. That means the will weigh (force caused by gravity) of about 9.8 Newtons which is about 2.2 pounds for those who use imperial units.

Now just ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ substitute steel/lead for water and feather for air and you get the same ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ result.

When idiots talk about which is heavier they talk about which would hurt more if it fells on you. A block or ball of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ metal versus a clump of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ feather that not held together in any way and thus would not act as one unit/mass and then turn into a bunch of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ individual feathers than do not weight 1 pound individually. Now, because of the shape and density of the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ feather there is a ♥♥♥♥ ton of drag force (air resistance) acting on those individual feather prevent them from accelerating as fast. If you were to hold them they would exert the same amount of force/weight on hands. If they were to drop on your head they would exert the same force because they have the same mass and gravity is the same everywhere on Earth (for practical purposes). The difference being that if steel/lead fall on your head, it would be a smaller object because it is denser and because it is a single object held incredibly tightly together due to inter-atomic/molecular forces. Compare that to a bundle of feathers not held together, all of a sudden you drop this bundle then all of a sudden they split up because they are a bunch of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ individual feather that are not held together. They will end up separating then all of a sudden you are hit by a bunch of individual feathers that do not weigh a pound that are hitting you, they are not even accelerating at normal gravitational acceleration because of the drag force (air resistance) acting on. Of course the pound of steel is going to hit ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ harder, its one object that is not being affected by drag (air resistance) to the same degree as the bunch of individual feathers not being held together (much, much less than the feathers). Even if the feathers were held together it still wouldn't hit harder because it is less dense and thus needs more volume to get to 1 pound, because it takes up more space there is more area for friction/drag (air resistance) to act upon thus it won't accelerate as fast in free fall. Just because one would hit hard in that situation does not mean one weighs more than the other because like I said before it is a product of mass and gravity and because gravity is constant and in this situation they have the same as well they will weigh the same. 1 kilogram of steel multiplied by the acceleration due to gravity gives you 9.8 Newtons (2.2 pounds). 1 kilogram of feathers multiplied by the acceleration due to gravity gives you 9.8 Newtons (2.2 pounds). Therefore, a pound (or kilogram in my example) of feather WEIGHS AND HAS THE SAME MASS as a pound (kilogram in my examples) of steel/lead.

If you don't understand that pound of feathers and a pound of steel weigh the same there is no TLDR, you need to read this whole thing. I could make this longer but if you don't understand the basic concept of mass and weight then me making this longer will not do you any good.

Anyone who does not understand this is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ idiot and needs to go back to middle school or high school where you should have learned this ♥♥♥♥, if you school never taught you this then everyone in charge of the decision making when it comes to curriculum should be replaced with someone who isn't ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ stupid.

I have, as of the 8th December 2023, 100% completed New Vegas. Within 500 hours I have gotten every achievement, completed every ending, tried out every gun and I must say:
The game is bizarre in how great the stories, quests and rpg-mechanics are, and how unapologetically awful everything else is. 
I like the graphics because it still conveys everything needed without frying my pc. 
I hate the map design because you'll spend twice as long just walking from point A to B than you will actually doing anything. 
I love the way crippling actually affects gameplay, like how you can cripple a cazador's wings to render it grounded and slow, or how you can shoot explosives while enemy humanoids are about to throw them to blow them up, but aiming outside of vats feels like yelling instructions at a blind and deaf peroplegic, both because of various glitches and because of mechanics like "sticky trigger" meant to provide immersion which just end up breaking it. 
But the absolute worst are the bugs. I know, like, half of them have been fixed by the community through mods, but that doesn't excuse it, nor does the rushed developement.
Games like Cyberpunk 2077, No Man's Sky, even Fallout 76 had far worse releases and yet they got fixed. A game that got as much attention and acclaim as New Vegas should've been able to fix those themselves. Instead, we got 4 story DLCs of which only Honest Hearts doesn't have blatant flaws. Old World Blues has over-leveled enemies that take entire buckets of ammo each, with Lobotomites that can pick up dropped weapons a mile away and somehow find plasma grenades in otherwise empty trash bins. Dead Money feels like something Bethesda Fallout would have. And Lonesome Road is amazing except for Ulyssies who would actually be a genuinely interesting character if he didn't speak in redditor, making his story so incredibly vague and difficult to understand that most people still don't know why he wants to nuke the long 15.

I loved New Vegas, hence why I dedicated 20+ days worth of time in it and agree that its the best Fallout game, but I would like for us to take a moment to acknowledge that "best Fallout game" is a very low bar to cross. Its a very good game.

PLAY THIS GAME. 

Not playing this game is a disservice to yourself. It's a classic, but still holds up to this day and I would argue, is still one of the BEST games I've ever played. If I could wipe my memory and play this game for the first time over again I'd do it, and then promptly wipe it again so I could do it a third time. 

Fallout New Vegas is a beautifully crafted example of what games can and should strive to be. There is never a dull moment, you will feel the impact you make within the world and it's very very rich and well written story. In Every other Fallout title (3 and 4) I skipped the main story and had fucked off to do what I wanted because the game gave me such a narrow scope to play the ROLE PLAYING game. But I was hooked instantly by this game by literally being shot in the damn face. 

That being said. This game is not without it's bugs. A common one I ran into was the continue option loading forever. Uninstall and then re download. I recommend using the 'load' option and physically select your latest save file you'd like to start from. And sometimes when using scoped weapons the scope was blurry like I was looking through a kaleidoscope. Save, quit your game, shut down and then restart the program. 

However, to discount this game because of 2010 bugs would be a crime.

That all being said. Go get shot by Benny. Trust me, the game is completely worth it, with or without Steam sale.

I honestly can't believe that this is $10 now - some people play for at least a thousand hours and still find things they didn't discover before, like hidden dialogue. 

It feels like I've explored every corner of this game, yet I also know there are still entire locations I've missed. 

Your choices, character composition, and playstyle matter. If you are good enough at sneaking, you can skip right past all the enemies. Shortly after doing so you realize this is a terrible idea when you accidentally alert a patrol, and everything in the vicinity attacks you all at once.

It is insanity that Obsidian developed this game in the time that they did, and how they were screwed by a certain shameless mainstream media reviewer by one point.

This franchise deserves to be in better hands than Bethesda in my opinion. If you haven't already played this, do yourself a favor. 

(Also, after you get used to/learn more about the game, try mods.)

Initially I avoided playing New Vegas because I had tried Fallout 3 and 4 and bounced off hard. After being battered with youtube videos that contained nothing but effusive praise for the game, I grudgingly gave it a shot and I am glad I did. In many ways it feels like a shining example of what a modern Western RPG should be, filled with great characters, great stories, and fascinating choices to make. The DLCs are possibly even better, with strong narratives that are not only great self-contained stories, they connect to major background characters in the main game and build up to the final DLC, Lonesome Road. The only downside is playing RPGs afterward won't feel the same again; "why can't these games be as good as New Vegas" will nag you for a long time.

Note: I played with the set of mods listed by Viva New Vegas to improve stability and performance issues. I did not use any content mods outside of Better Brotherhood. Even with these mods installed, I still had occasional crashes; it is not the most stable of games.

It leaves the player wanted to play again and again to experiment with the different paths and discover hidden secrets that were missed previously. The game is also easily modifiable, with hundreds of supporters still making mods that allow for a different player experience or more stable running. All in all, Fall Out: New Vegas is, without a doubt, one of the best Fallout game ever made.

This isn't about the actual quality of the game, but rather a unique issue for players living in Germany. Due to the concern of kids going on steam and playing mature content, Germany censors some 18+ games on the platform, including this one. While the censorship is annoying, that's not my main issue. If you're German, chances are you purchase, download and open New Vegas only to realize it's hard stuck in the German language. You want to experience the original version and voice actors? You simply prefer a different language? You happen to purchase the game while in Germany but don't know how to speak German? There is no way to change this, you will have to play the game in German.

The store page gives you a warning that the "low violence version" is only in German, yet you are not told before, during or even after your purchase which version of the game the censored one actually is. For those wondering, it's the standard version. If you want to play the game in any other language you will need to buy the ultimate version and pay double the price. I'm sure the extra content is great, but I should not have to pay double just to play in my preferred language to appeal to a law that was made for people younger than me. If that is asking for too much then at least label it properly instead of giving a vague warning mentioning a low violence version.

There is one thing, one glaring flaw with this game that I cannot possibly overlook. It is so egregious that I can only just barely squeak out a recommendation. What's that you ask? Well, Radio New Vegas cautioned that you should not taunt a super mutant for taking the bunny slope at the ski resort. So you [b]know[/b] what I was fixing to do when I got to the Jacobstown Ski Resort. That's right; taunt a super mutant for taking the bunny slope. It is with great disappointment that I must inform potential buyers of this game that, despite what the radio man suggests, [i]there are [b]NO[/b] super mutants to bully for taking bunny slopes[/i]. 

Absolute travesty of a design decision! This game would be a complete 0/10 if it weren't for the amazing character system and the whole rest of the world Obsidian created.

I joke; I kidd of course. 9/10 game. Because wow does it have depth and wow does it actually allow role playing! It did take me about 10 hours for it really hook me. But when it did, it was obvious why this is the most beloved Fallout game. New Vegas actually feels like a real, living world that you could find 200 years after a global nuclear war with real decisions to be made that matter. Fallout 3 in retrospect looks farcical. 200 years after a nuclear holocaust, and all there is a raiding gangs fighting over prewar food, yet some of them somehow have working power armor? Right. Sure.

As for gameplay, well standard Gamebryo complaints i.e. bugs, glitches, iffy graphics, bad animations, [i]awful[/i] gunplay. But these are really unremarkable compared to the branching possibilities in quest lines, world depth, and you'll be 2-hitting most things by late game anyways.

I love this game and appreciate all of the effort that went into making it. With that being said there are flaws and bugs all over, you cant find a fallout without bugs. but that's not what you should be looking for in a fallout game. You could speak all day about the bugs or crashes or lack of any real quality graphics but that's just how good this game is. You will love this game despite all of it's flaws, if you love games for graphics or perfection this just simply isn't for you.

 If you like games for fun, interesting lore, captivating stories, and maybe a little gambling on the side then this is your game. I think if you haven't played a fallout game then you're just simply missing out on a wonderful series of games. Even the first few fallout games are still good, different than a first person shooter but still good in their own way.

 I encourage you to buy this and experience the magic of fallout or get it to replay it, do all of the side quests or don't. Be good or be bad or do whatever the heck you want. That's the beauty of fallout NV, you can do whatever you want and you get to pick your side and who you help, or who you destroy. If you didn't like the outcome you can always do another play-through. 

If this sounds good to you at all then pull the trigger and buy it, you won't regret it at all.

Fallout New Vegas is a masterpiece. The game does everything right in terms of story, progression, weapons, environments, characters. It starts off with such a strong hook, your character gets shot in the head and you are looking for revenge, and carries that hook throughout the whole of the main story. Not only that, but every single location in the game is unique and interesting, and many out of the way areas are directly pointed to for various quests, so you won't miss these incredibly interesting and captivating locations.

Not only this, however, but every character you come across is interesting and fleshed out in their own right. Hell, even certain throw-away characters are fleshed out more than characters in other games, who are suppose to be "main" characters. You have a vast range of different personalities, from ruthless fascistic dictators, to drunk caravan girls, and even gay scientists. 

This game also does moral dilemmas incredibly well, giving you reasons to do certain things, even if they may seem "bad" or "evil". There are always reasons behind the evil, and that leads to incentives for siding with the choices which are morally worse. On top of this, these moral dilemmas lead directly into what makes the main story so great. Every faction that you find throughout the Mojave isn't necessarily evil, but they're also not perfect, either. The NCR look to bring order to the Mojave, but they lack the manpower to do so, and most residents in the desert don't support their encroaching grasp, either. The Legion slaughter all who oppose them, enslaving or forcefully recruiting the survivors, but they see this as the only way to maintain a strong grasp on the wastes, and to keep their people protected. Mr. House wants to expand the Strip, making it into the waste's largest money-making machine. He can protect the Mojave with his army of robots, however in doing so, he also keeps New Vegas segregated.

All of these small things lead to a story that is interesting and enticing which easily holds your attention and keeps you hooked. Even more impressive, however, is that this game was made in 18 months.

Oh, also, being bisexual is objectively the strongest choice you can make in the game, and you can also recruit a sex robot, so that should automatically sell you on this game, if you aren't already sold.

Before I begin this review I want to make this clear I'm a fan of both Fallout 3 and New Vegas and I like them both equally. With that being said let us begin,

What is Fallout New Vegas? Why is it so popular? Why do players keep coming back to it? I'll answer all of these questions. First of all Fallout New Vegas is obviously a game that takes place in the Fallout universe and there is no such bs as "different universe" or "different timeline" it takes place 4 years after the events of Fallout 3 however it has no direct connection to Fallout 3. You play as a courier who got nailed by a dude in a checkered suit and his "mercs" for hire, I won't say anything else as that would be a spoiler however the game isn't just about getting your revenge it is MUCH MORE than that.

Why is it popular? Memorable characters, New and reworked guns and gameplay mechanics, The details in this game are top notch, modding support, virtually infinite replayability value and much much more. Suffice to say you will play this game more than once if you give it a go. Even at the time of writing this I have almost 260 hours on record and I'm not done with FNV I have many more hours to sink into this game.

Now, Why do players keep coming back to it? Although I already gave the reason for this previously but I'll say it again its because of the modding support and replayability value this game offers. There are quite a few endings to this game and even in my 260 hours I haven't seen all of them.

Now that I've answered all the question its time for the verdict. Absolutely recommended, However consider buying the game on discount with all the dlcs. Despite being given only 18 months to work on this Obsidian came through and delivered a gem

I first played this game on xbox 360. Then I picked it up on steam years ago when I was much younger and fell in love with this game. The world is incredible if you immerse yourself in it. It really gives you a more raw feel then its cinematic fallout 3 counterpart. A couple things i loved about this game was unique weapons, weapon mods, ammo, the superior writing and story, the characters, and the dlcs. I remember I got really immersed in the mods for this game. Its been a very long time since i've played this game on computer (which I think is the best experience) but i passed by it on gamepass for xbox 2 months back and downloaded it, and what do you know I fully completed the entire game and all dlcs with a smile on my face. I don't know If this game just reminds me of good old innocent memories or if its really that good but either way, it gives a feeling to me that just pulls me in. It holds a very special place in my heart that no other game has really ever been able to fulfill yet. Some come close, but never quite this special.

I've played this on both PC and Console. I have to say, this is the better experience. Keyboard and Mouse feels 100x better than Controller. Outside of that, I have never really gotten too far into the game because of how badly the controls felt on console, but so far I am almost 10 hours in, and I am really enjoying it. I used to think "whats the big deal with New Vegas" but I think I finally understand it. One thing that I will say is lacking is the ability to sprint. It makes actually traversing the world a little annoying, to the point where it almost encourages you to fast travel almost every time vs. walking/exploring.

Fallout: New Vegas?

The universe of the post-nuclear Mojave Desert is given to life by its distinctive multi-branched story with twists and turns. and its characters
While the graphics in this game have aged like milk over the years, that should not deter you from its great setting and lore.

Any serious Fallout fan must complete this game at least once!

In my opinion, with about 1109 hours invested in this game (played extensively on XBOX 360), this stands as the best Fallout game ever released. Yes, the gunfight mechanics are dated, the graphics far from perfect, and the game often struggles to run smoothly. However, the storytelling, unparalleled world-building, captivating DLCs, and the overall immersive ambiance have driven me to replay it nearly 10 times. If you're seeking Fallout at its pinnacle, this game is a must-play.

Furthermore, consider modding the game to avoid frequent crashes:https://vivanewvegas.github.io/index.html

27-100+ hours to complete, Fallout: New Vegas is a post-apocalyptic desert wasteland survival open-world RPG with enough content and questlines to seriously keep you busy. While the graphics are outdated, the gameplay is very exciting with each playthrough feeling different due to the various ways you can solve a questline, the multiple factions to join, and the various game endings to find. In addition, I highly recommend purchasing the DLCs, as they introduce new maps, weapons, items, apparel and npcs to keep things fresh. However, due to Bethesda being notorious for their bugs, I sincerely recommend downloading an anti-crash and game stabilization mods from Nexus.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3007323601
I had an unforgettable time playing Fallout: New Vegas for two reasons, one, it’s genuinely a fun and incredible game, and two, the insane game crash rate I experienced in the DLCs. Old World Blues must have been over thirty, and Honest Hearts was unplayable. I dropped the game for about three months to take a break, and upon coming back, the game seemed to have fixed itself somehow, as I only crashed once in Dead Money. Despite the game's unreliable stability (or reliable instability), it’s still worth buying and playing, although personally, I like Fallout 4 more by a significant margin.

An Unforgettable Journey Through the Wasteland
Rating: ★★★★★
_________________________________

From the moment you step into the post-apocalyptic Mojave Wasteland, the depth and complexity of the world become apparent. The narrative is a triumph, offering a branching storyline filled with moral ambiguity, political intrigue, and memorable characters. Your choices carry weight, shaping the fate of the Mojave and leaving a lasting impact on the world around you.

The level of freedom in character development is outstanding. Whether you choose to be a smooth-talking diplomat, a skilled marksman, or a tech-savvy scientist, the game accommodates your playstyle, providing a truly personalized experience. The depth of the role-playing mechanics, combined with the well-crafted dialogue, creates a sense of immersion rarely seen in gaming.

New Vegas doesn't just excel in storytelling; its open-world design encourages exploration and discovery. Every location, from the iconic New Vegas Strip to the desolate outskirts, is packed with lore, secrets, and dynamic encounters. The attention to detail in the world-building is remarkable, making the Wasteland feel like a living, breathing entity.

In conclusion, Fallout: New Vegas is a triumph of storytelling, player agency, and world-building. Its replay value is immense, thanks to the diverse narrative paths and the sheer number of choices at your disposal. If you haven't experienced the Mojave Wasteland yet, do yourself a favor and dive into this gaming masterpiece. It's a solid 5/5 from me, and a journey I'll never forget.

Bethesda may have brought Fallout into the world of ARPGs, but Obsidian with their know-how of CRPGs brought the full potential of what a really meaty and replayable ARPG could achieve. Outside of the writing and some really great decisions for roleplaying, this game doesn't do a few things great, but instead does everything decently. That might sound like a backhanded compliment, and yet, what I mean by saying this is that the game works well enough [despite the bugs and crashes] to feel like a real world. I have yet to find this level of immersion in any other game. A player might accidentally break their legs and need to hoof it to the nearest doctor. Maybe you tick off one of the two major opposing factions enough that they send assassins after you. Every now and then you'll get a quest where you get to play a bit of a detective, use your medical skills to patch patients up, save some hostages, play a soldier, play a scumbag, help some goofballs fly off on a rocket, delve into deathclaw country and live to tell about it, and so many other fun possibilities. The game is fairly old, it does have bugs and crashing issues, but it's so much fun that I and many others have found the patience to roll with the issues.

Grab New Vegas on sale, and give it a try. You'll not only find a really rewarding game, but one that can be replayed many, many times. My playtime as of writing this is around 158 hours, but trust me, I've easily spent closer to 1,000 hours on console and on other devices.

Fallout: New Vegas, the fourth installment in the iconic Fallout series, stands as a testament to the beauty that can be found in the post-apocalyptic wasteland. Released in 2010, this game has captivated players with its unique blend of storytelling, atmospheric design, and a rich, immersive world. In this essay, we will delve into the beauty of Fallout: New Vegas, exploring the game's visual aesthetics, narrative depth, and the emotional resonance it evokes.

Visual Aesthetics:

One cannot discuss the beauty of Fallout: New Vegas without acknowledging its stunning visual design. Despite the desolation of the Mojave Wasteland, the game manages to portray a hauntingly beautiful world. The sunsets over the barren landscape, the dilapidated remains of iconic landmarks like the New Vegas Strip, and the contrasting hues of the radioactive glow all contribute to an atmosphere that is both melancholic and mesmerizing.

The game's attention to detail in depicting the aftermath of nuclear devastation is remarkable. From the rusted skeletons of cars scattered across the desert to the twisted metal remnants of once-thriving communities, the visuals tell a silent yet poignant story of a world that has faced the unimaginable. The desolate beauty of the Mojave Wasteland, with its harsh landscapes and abandoned structures, invites players to explore and discover the narratives embedded within the ruins.

Narrative Depth:

Beneath the surface of Fallout: New Vegas lies a narrative tapestry woven with intricate threads of political intrigue, moral ambiguity, and existential contemplation. The game's beauty extends beyond its visual appeal to the depth of its storytelling. The player assumes the role of the Courier, a protagonist with a mysterious past, navigating a world teeming with factions vying for control.

The multiple branching storylines and morally ambiguous choices add layers of complexity to the narrative, creating a dynamic and immersive experience. The beauty lies not just in the grandeur of the overarching plot but in the small, intimate stories scattered throughout the wasteland. Each character, no matter how minor, contributes to the narrative mosaic, offering glimpses into the human condition and the resilience of the human spirit in the face of adversity.

Emotional Resonance:

The beauty of Fallout: New Vegas transcends the visual and narrative aspects, reaching into the emotional core of the player. The haunting melodies of the game's soundtrack, composed by Inon Zur, enhance the atmosphere, evoking a sense of loneliness, nostalgia, and hope. The emotional impact of the game is heightened by the interconnectedness of the characters and the consequences of the player's choices.

The relationships forged, the alliances formed, and the betrayals endured create an emotional investment that lingers long after the game is completed. The beauty lies in the emotional rollercoaster, from the elation of triumph to the pang of regret for decisions made. It prompts players to reflect on the consequences of their actions, blurring the line between right and wrong in a morally ambiguous world.

Conclusion:

Fallout: New Vegas stands as a masterpiece not only in the realm of gaming but also as a work of art that transcends the medium. Its beauty is multifaceted, encompassing the visual splendor of the Mojave Wasteland, the narrative depth of its storytelling, and the emotional resonance it elicits from players. In the vast expanse of the post-apocalyptic landscape, Fallout: New Vegas finds beauty in the ruins, inviting players to explore, reflect, and appreciate the enduring human spirit in the face of desolation.

Fallout: New Vegas is a timeless gem that seamlessly blends a captivating narrative with the vast, unforgiving landscapes of the Mojave Wasteland. From the moment you step out of Doc Mitchell's clinic, you're thrust into a world brimming with moral ambiguity, complex characters, and a plethora of choices that shape your journey.

Obsidian Entertainment's attention to detail shines through in the rich storytelling, offering multiple branching paths that ensure each playthrough is a unique experience. The morally gray decisions you face have consequences that ripple throughout the Mojave, affecting factions, allies, and the overall outcome of your quest.

The game's atmosphere is enhanced by a hauntingly beautiful soundtrack, echoing the desolation and struggles of post-apocalyptic life. The Mojave feels alive, with its diverse environments, from the neon-lit streets of New Vegas to the treacherous expanses of the desert, each teeming with its own challenges and secrets.

While the graphics may show signs of aging, the immersive world, engaging quests, and memorable characters more than make up for it. With a plethora of mods available, you can enhance your experience and breathe new life into this classic title.

Fallout: New Vegas stands as a testament to the enduring appeal of the Fallout series, delivering an unforgettable journey through a morally complex and atmospheric wasteland. Whether you're a seasoned wasteland wanderer or a newcomer to the series, this game is a must-play for anyone seeking a gripping RPG adventure.

I still get that feeling when you see The B-52 in action or the end slides for characters that don't speak English and you just gotta hope your decisions made their ending good, all the wild wasteland encounters, the emotional attachment you make to Characters, SHOOTING THAT LOTTERY TICKET GUY EVERY TIME. The good needs to outweigh the bad in games and Fallout: New Vegas' good is much more plentiful than its bad. 9.5/10 thank you to the creative minds at Obsidian and RIP Interplay.

Hey, hey, it's Mr. New Vegas letting you know I've got a new Christmas compilation coming out soon; Nuclear Winter Wonderland. Look for it, on holotape. It's just about time to get you some news. A package courier found shot in the head near Goodsprings has reportedly regained consciousness, and has made a full recovery. Now that is a delivery service you can count on. NCR officials at Camp McCarran were relieved when technical difficulties with its monorail line to the New Vegas Strip proved easy to fix. One anonymous official told us a serious mechanical failure would have been a disaster because of the age of the train and the scarcity of the replacement parts. Citizens of Outer Vegas are flocking to the Strip in droves amid a wave of terror caused by a band of raiders known as the Fiends. Those who can afford passports say that the added security is well worth the price of admission. Troubling news from Primm, as merchants report a large presence of armed and unsavoury figures patrolling the town. Residents are nowhere to be found. The HELIOS One solar power plant remains dormant, despite NCR's effort to reactivate the facility. The chief scientist of the plant vowed to fix the problem, blaming it on an atmosphere of quote severe under-appreciation. This program was brought you by Gomorrah. Gomorrah: It'll be our secret. When I first played New Vegas, my reaction was fairly lukewarm. I got the game when it was released back in 2010 for PS3. I was a 16-year-old kid who didn’t care about the story, nor could I really wrap my head around all of the political themes that pervade this game. I just wanted it to be more Fallout 3 where I ran around and made heads explode in V.A.T.S. In this regard, I was disappointed. The game’s story is much deeper than what is offered in Fallout 3. I got the Ultimate Edition 2 years ago during the summer sale because I never played the DLC and got it for ~$7. Since then it has become one of my most played games on Steam and one of my favorite games of all time, so I figured I should write a review and explain why I love this game so much.

New Vegas’s greatest strength is its understanding of player choice. Obsidian made an effort to make sure that you actually have multiple choices in most (if not all) scenarios. When most games think of choice, they think you have the freedom to be either the second coming of Christ, or Satan incarnate. They take a binary approach with no middle ground. I’m sorry for opening up this old flame war, but I would use Bethesda’s quest design as an example of the binary choice I’m talking about. Fallout 3 gave you the option of either being a goody-two-shoes, or a horrible monster who is the scourge of the wasteland. In New Vegas, you can tackle every situation in multiple ways depending on how you want to play the game. Maybe you can talk your way out with the speech skill, or pass a sneak check to avoid combat. Your skills and the character you decide to play truly matter in this game. The game is less focused on the karma system of Fallout 3, and, as a result, is not as limited. There is no one right answer to many of the problems in this game.

The gameplay and combat are adequate, but, admittedly, could be much better. It has shooting system that is standard for most games nowadays, where you can shoot from the hip or aim down the sights if you wish to be more accurate. It does a decent enough job, but it does not compare to other games with a more combat-heavy focus. Guns have almost no recoil and are laser accurate, which can get boring if you use automatics. Melee and unarmed are extremely viable and are probably my favorite way to play the vanilla game. They give the game a more Skyrim/Oblivion-type feel. You’ll have fun no matter what type of weaponry you choose to specialize in, but the gunplay does feel clunky at times.

The biggest problem with this game is that it can crash a lot. My crashes did not seem as frequent as some of the others that I have read about, but I still would save very often. The game has some goofy glitches too that can occasionally screw up quests too (thankfully, since this is the PC edition, you can fix broken quests with console commands). The technical issues come because the game was developed in only 18 months, reusing most of the assets from Fallout 3. That’s not an excuse, but it gives you an idea of some of the problems in this game. 

 Overall, there is tons of content in this game. My first PC playthrough clocked in around 70 hours, and that was even when I knew where I was going. It’s definitely worth the money, and still holds up today. If you haven’t already, buy it and see what all the hype is about.

5/5
--------------------------------------------

I also want to talk about mods, but didn’t want to let it impact my review. The mods in this game take what is already a great game and make it damn near perfect. As I mentioned before, the fundamentals of this game are solid, and mods expand on that. Additionally There are so many great ones out there, and people are still modding it today. Most of my playtime is probably from just going through the countless mods that are out there and seeing what is offered. They can fix some of the problems in this game, and add seemingly endless amounts of new content. If you play this game and don’t mod it, you’re missing out on the best part.

**I must also mention that many people who buy this game lately are experiencing issues with crashing. This is due to a Windows update that broke something. Installing the New Vegas Anti Crash (NVAC) mod should fix this problem
